**Dublin** ^[\[A\]](#cite_note-12)^ is the [capital city](/wiki/Capital_city "Capital city") of [Ireland](/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland "Republic of Ireland").^[\[11\]](#cite_note-13)^^[\[12\]](#cite_note-14)^ On [a bay](/wiki/Dublin_Bay "Dublin Bay") at the mouth of the [River Liffey](/wiki/River_Liffey "River Liffey"), it is in the [province](/wiki/Provinces_of_Ireland "Provinces of Ireland") of [Leinster](/wiki/Leinster "Leinster"), bordered on the south by the Dublin Mountains, a part of the [Wicklow Mountains](/wiki/Wicklow_Mountains "Wicklow Mountains") range. At the [2022 census](/wiki/2022_census_of_Ireland "2022 census of Ireland"), the city council area had a population of 592,713, while Dublin and its suburbs had a population of 1,263,219, and [County Dublin](/wiki/County_Dublin "County Dublin") had a population of 1,501,500,^[\[3\]](#cite_note-2022mapdcc-3)^^[\[13\]](#cite_note-2022mapdcands-15)^^[\[14\]](#cite_note-16)^ making it the largest city by population on the island of [Ireland](/wiki/Ireland "Ireland").{#cite_ref-16}

A settlement was established in the area by the [Gaels](/wiki/Gaels "Gaels") during or before the 7th century,^[\[15\]](#cite_note-dicksonX-17)^ followed by the [Vikings](/wiki/Viking "Viking"). As the [Kingdom of Dublin](/wiki/Kings_of_Dublin "Kings of Dublin") grew, it became Ireland's principal settlement by the 12th century [Anglo-Norman invasion of Ireland](/wiki/Anglo-Norman_invasion_of_Ireland "Anglo-Norman invasion of Ireland").^[\[15\]](#cite_note-dicksonX-17)^ The city expanded rapidly from the 17th century and was briefly the second largest in the [British Empire](/wiki/British_Empire "British Empire") and sixth largest in [Western Europe](/wiki/Western_Europe "Western Europe") after the [Acts of Union](/wiki/Acts_of_Union_1800 "Acts of Union 1800") in 1800.^[\[16\]](#cite_note-18)^ Following independence in 1922, Dublin became the capital of the [Irish Free State](/wiki/Irish_Free_State "Irish Free State"), [renamed Ireland](/wiki/Names_of_the_Irish_State "Names of the Irish State") in 1937. As of 2018^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit)^, the city was listed by the [Globalization and World Cities Research Network](/wiki/Globalization_and_World_Cities_Research_Network "Globalization and World Cities Research Network") (GaWC) as a [global city](/wiki/Global_city "Global city"), with a ranking of "Alpha minus", which placed it among the top thirty cities in the world.^[\[17\]](#cite_note-19)^^[\[18\]](#cite_note-20)^{#cite_ref-20}  

Etymology {#Etymology}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Etymology")\]  
See also: [Other names of Dublin](/wiki/Names_of_European_cities_in_different_languages:_C%E2%80%93D#D "Names of European cities in different languages: C–D")

The name *Dublin* comes from the [Middle Irish](/wiki/Middle_Irish "Middle Irish") word *Du(i)blind* (literally "Blackpool"),^[\[19\]](#cite_note-:2-21)^ from *dubh* [\[d̪ˠuβˠ\]](/wiki/Help:IPA "Help:IPA") "black, dark" and *linn* [\[l̠ʲin̠ʲ(dʲ)\]](/wiki/Help:IPA "Help:IPA") "pool". This evolved into the [Early Modern Irish](/wiki/Early_Modern_Irish "Early Modern Irish") form *Du(i)bhlinn*,^[\[19\]](#cite_note-:2-21)^ which was pronounced "Duílinn" [\[ˈd̪ˠiːlʲin̠ʲ\]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Irish "Help:IPA/Irish") in the [local dialect](/wiki/Irish_language#Leinster "Irish language"). The name refers to a dark tidal pool on the site of the castle gardens at the rear of [Dublin Castle](/wiki/Dublin_Castle "Dublin Castle"), where the [River Poddle](/wiki/River_Poddle "River Poddle") entered the [Liffey](/wiki/River_Liffey "River Liffey").{#cite_ref-:2_21-1}

The Middle Irish pronunciation is preserved in the names for the city in other languages such as [Old English](/wiki/Old_English "Old English") *Difelin*, [Old Norse](/wiki/Old_Norse "Old Norse") *Dyflin*, modern [Icelandic](/wiki/Icelandic_language "Icelandic language") *Dyflinn* and modern [Manx](/wiki/Manx_language "Manx language") *Divlyn* as well as [Welsh](/wiki/Welsh_language "Welsh language") *Dulyn* and [Breton](/wiki/Breton_language "Breton language") *Dulenn*. Other localities in Ireland also bear the name *Duibhlinn* , variously anglicised as Devlin,^[\[20\]](#cite_note-22)^ Divlin^[\[21\]](#cite_note-23)^ and Difflin.^[\[22\]](#cite_note-24)^ Variations on the name are also found in traditionally Gaelic-speaking areas of [Scotland](/wiki/Scotland "Scotland") ([Gàidhealtachd](/wiki/G%C3%A0idhealtachd "Gàidhealtachd"), cognate with Irish [Gaeltacht](/wiki/Gaeltacht "Gaeltacht")), such as *An Linne Dhubh* ("the black pool"), which is part of [Loch Linnhe](/wiki/Loch_Linnhe "Loch Linnhe").{#cite_ref-24}

It is now thought that the Viking settlement was preceded by a Christian ecclesiastical settlement known as *Duibhlinn* , from which *Dyflin* took its name.^[\[23\]](#cite_note-25)^ Beginning in the 9th and 10th centuries, there were two settlements where the modern city stands. The Viking settlement of about 841, *Dyflin* , and a Gaelic settlement, Áth Cliath ("ford of hurdles")^[\[24\]](#cite_note-26)^ further up the river, at the present-day [Father Mathew Bridge](/wiki/Father_Mathew_Bridge "Father Mathew Bridge") (also known as Dublin Bridge), at the bottom of Church Street.{#cite_ref-26}

*Baile Átha Cliath*, meaning "town of the hurdled [ford](/wiki/Ford_(crossing) "Ford (crossing)")", is the common name for the city in Modern Irish, which is often contracted to *Bleá Cliath* or *Blea Cliath* when spoken.^[\[25\]](#cite_note-27)^ *Áth Cliath* is a place name referring to a fording point of the River Liffey near Father Mathew Bridge. **Baile Átha Cliath** was an early Christian monastery, believed to have been in the area of Aungier Street, currently occupied by [Whitefriar Street Carmelite Church](/wiki/Whitefriar_Street_Carmelite_Church "Whitefriar Street Carmelite Church"). There are other towns of the same name, such as *Àth Cliath* in [East Ayrshire](/wiki/East_Ayrshire "East Ayrshire"), Scotland, which is anglicised as [Hurlford](/wiki/Hurlford "Hurlford").{#cite_ref-27}  

History {#History}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: History")\]  
Main article: [History of Dublin](/wiki/History_of_Dublin "History of Dublin")  
For a chronological guide, see [Timeline of Dublin](/wiki/Timeline_of_Dublin "Timeline of Dublin").

The area of [Dublin Bay](/wiki/Dublin_Bay "Dublin Bay") has been inhabited by humans since prehistoric times; fish traps discovered from excavations during the construction of the [Convention Centre Dublin](/wiki/Convention_Centre_Dublin "Convention Centre Dublin") indicate human habitation as far back as 6,000 years ago. Further traps were discovered closer to the old settlement of the city of Dublin on the [south quays](/wiki/Dublin_quays "Dublin quays") near [St. James's Gate](/wiki/St._James%27s_Gate "St. James's Gate") which also indicate [mesolithic](/wiki/Mesolithic "Mesolithic") human activity.^[\[26\]](#cite_note-28)^^[\[27\]](#cite_note-29)^{#cite_ref-29}

[Ptolemy's map of Ireland](/wiki/Ptolemy%27s_map_of_Ireland "Ptolemy's map of Ireland"), of about 140 AD, provides possibly the earliest reference to a settlement near Dublin. [Ptolemy](/wiki/Ptolemy "Ptolemy"), the Greco-Roman astronomer and [cartographer](/wiki/Cartographer "Cartographer"), called it *[Eblana](/wiki/Eblana "Eblana") polis* ([Ancient Greek](/wiki/Ancient_Greek_language "Ancient Greek language"): Ἔβλανα πόλις).^[\[28\]](#cite_note-Holder-30)^{#cite_ref-Holder_30-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Dublin_-_Dublinia_-_20190809102938.jpg/220px-Dublin_-_Dublinia_-_20190809102938.jpg)](/wiki/File:Dublin_-_Dublinia_-_20190809102938.jpg) A statue of a [Viking](/wiki/Vikings "Vikings") on a [longship](/wiki/Longship "Longship") in Dublin [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Dublin_-_Father_Mathew_Bridge_-_110508_182542.jpg/220px-Dublin_-_Father_Mathew_Bridge_-_110508_182542.jpg)](/wiki/File:Dublin_-_Father_Mathew_Bridge_-_110508_182542.jpg) [Father Mathew Bridge](/wiki/Father_Mathew_Bridge "Father Mathew Bridge"), also known as Dublin Bridge

Dublin celebrated its 'official' millennium in 1988, meaning the Irish government recognised 988 as the year in which the city was settled and that this first settlement would later become the city of Dublin.^[\[29\]](#cite_note-it1986-31)^{#cite_ref-it1986_31-0}

It is now thought^[\[30\]](#cite_note-32)^ the Viking settlement of about 841 was preceded by a Christian ecclesiastical settlement known as *Duibhlinn* , from which *Dyflin* took its name. Evidence indicating that Anglo-Saxons occupied Dublin before the Vikings arrived in 841 has been found in an archaeological dig in [Temple Bar](/wiki/Temple_Bar,_Dublin "Temple Bar, Dublin").^[\[31\]](#cite_note-33)^{#cite_ref-33}

Beginning in the 9th and 10th centuries, there were two settlements which later became modern Dublin. The subsequent Scandinavian settlement centred on the [River Poddle](/wiki/River_Poddle "River Poddle"), a tributary of the Liffey in an area now known as [Wood Quay](/wiki/Wood_Quay "Wood Quay"). The Dubhlinn was a pool on the lowest stretch of the Poddle, where ships used to moor. This pool was finally fully infilled during the early 18th century, as the city grew. The Dubhlinn lay where the Castle Garden is now located, opposite the [Chester Beatty Library](/wiki/Chester_Beatty_Library "Chester Beatty Library") within [Dublin Castle](/wiki/Dublin_Castle "Dublin Castle"). *[Táin Bó Cuailgne](/wiki/T%C3%A1in_B%C3%B3_Cuailgne "Táin Bó Cuailgne")* ("The Cattle Raid of Cooley") refers to *Dublind rissa ratter Áth Cliath*, meaning "Dublin, which is called Ath Cliath".  

### Middle Ages {#Middle_Ages}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Middle Ages")\]

In 841, the [Vikings](/wiki/Vikings "Vikings") established a fortified base in Dublin.^[\[32\]](#cite_note-34)^ The town grew into a substantial commercial center under [Olaf Guthfrithson](/wiki/Olaf_Guthfrithson "Olaf Guthfrithson") in the mid-to-late 10th century^[\[33\]](#cite_note-35)^ and, despite a number of attacks by the native Irish, it remained largely under Viking control until the [Norman invasion of Ireland](/wiki/Norman_invasion_of_Ireland "Norman invasion of Ireland") was launched from Wales in 1169.^[\[34\]](#cite_note-Davies-36)^^[\[35\]](#cite_note-37)^ The [hinterland](/wiki/Hinterland "Hinterland") of Dublin in the Norse period was named in [Old Norse](/wiki/Old_Norse_language "Old Norse language"): *Dyflinnar skíði* , [lit.](/wiki/Literal_translation "Literal translation") 'Dublinshire'.^[\[36\]](#cite_note-38)^^: 24^ It was upon the death of [Muirchertach Mac Lochlainn](/wiki/Muirchertach_Mac_Lochlainn "Muirchertach Mac Lochlainn") in early 1166 that [Ruaidrí Ua Conchobair](/wiki/Ruaidr%C3%AD_Ua_Conchobair "Ruaidrí Ua Conchobair"), [King of Connacht](/wiki/King_of_Connacht "King of Connacht"), proceeded to Dublin and was inaugurated *King of Ireland* without opposition.{#cite_ref-38}

According to some historians, part of the city's early economic growth is attributed to a trade in slaves.^[\[37\]](#cite_note-dickson10-39)^ [Slavery in Ireland](/wiki/Slavery_in_Ireland "Slavery in Ireland") and Dublin reached its pinnacle in the 9th and 10th centuries.^[\[38\]](#cite_note-40)^ Prisoners from slave raids and kidnappings, which captured men, women and children, brought revenue to the Gaelic Irish Sea raiders, as well as to the Vikings who had initiated the practice.^[\[39\]](#cite_note-41)^ The victims came from [Wales](/wiki/Wales "Wales"), England, Normandy and beyond.^[\[37\]](#cite_note-dickson10-39)^{#cite_ref-dickson10_39-1}

The King of Leinster, [Diarmait Mac Murchada](/wiki/Diarmait_Mac_Murchada "Diarmait Mac Murchada"), after his exile by Ruaidhrí, enlisted the help of [Strongbow](/wiki/Richard_de_Clare,_2nd_Earl_of_Pembroke "Richard de Clare, 2nd Earl of Pembroke"), the Earl of Pembroke, to conquer Dublin. Following Mac Murchada's death, Strongbow declared himself King of Leinster after gaining control of the city. In response to Strongbow's successful invasion, [Henry II of England](/wiki/Henry_II_of_England "Henry II of England") affirmed his ultimate sovereignty by mounting a larger invasion in 1171 and pronounced himself [Lord of Ireland](/wiki/Lord_of_Ireland "Lord of Ireland").^[\[40\]](#cite_note-Dublin.info-42)^ Around this time, the *county of the City of Dublin* was established along with certain liberties adjacent to the city proper. This continued down to 1840 when the [barony](/wiki/Barony_(Ireland) "Barony (Ireland)") of Dublin City was separated from the [barony of Dublin](/wiki/Dublin_(barony) "Dublin (barony)"). Since 2001, both baronies have been redesignated as the *City of Dublin*.{#cite_ref-Dublin.info_42-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/The_Dubhlinn_Gardens_Dublin_Castle_01.JPG/220px-The_Dubhlinn_Gardens_Dublin_Castle_01.JPG)](/wiki/File:The_Dubhlinn_Gardens_Dublin_Castle_01.JPG) [Dublin Castle](/wiki/Dublin_Castle "Dublin Castle"), with its 13th-century tower, was the fortified seat of [British rule in Ireland](/wiki/British_rule_in_Ireland "British rule in Ireland") until 1922.

[Dublin Castle](/wiki/Dublin_Castle "Dublin Castle"), which became the centre of Anglo-Norman power in Ireland, was founded in 1204 as a major defensive work on the orders of King [John of England](/wiki/John_of_England "John of England").^[\[41\]](#cite_note-43)^ Following the appointment of the first [Lord Mayor of Dublin](/wiki/Lord_Mayor_of_Dublin "Lord Mayor of Dublin") in 1229, the city expanded and had a population of 8,000 by the end of the 13th century. Dublin prospered as a trade centre, despite an attempt by King [Robert the Bruce](/wiki/Robert_the_Bruce "Robert the Bruce") of Scotland to capture the city in 1317.^[\[40\]](#cite_note-Dublin.info-42)^ It remained a relatively small walled medieval town during the 14th century and was under constant threat from the surrounding native clans. In 1348, the [Black Death](/wiki/Black_Death "Black Death"), a lethal plague which had ravaged Europe, took hold in Dublin and killed thousands over the following decade.^[\[42\]](#cite_note-44)^^[\[43\]](#cite_note-45)^{#cite_ref-45}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Dublin_in_1610_-_reprint_of_1896.jpg/220px-Dublin_in_1610_-_reprint_of_1896.jpg)](/wiki/File:Dublin_in_1610_-_reprint_of_1896.jpg) Dubline, 1610; a contemporary map by John Speed (1896 reprint)

Dublin was the heart of the area known as [the Pale](/wiki/The_Pale "The Pale"), a narrow strip of English settlement along the eastern coast, under the control of the [English Crown](/wiki/English_Crown "English Crown"). The [Tudor conquest of Ireland](/wiki/Tudor_conquest_of_Ireland "Tudor conquest of Ireland") in the 16th century spelt a new era for Dublin, with the city enjoying a renewed prominence as the centre of administrative rule in Ireland where English control and settlement had become much more extensive. Determined to make Dublin a Protestant city, Queen [Elizabeth I](/wiki/Elizabeth_I "Elizabeth I") established [Trinity College](/wiki/Trinity_College_Dublin "Trinity College Dublin") in 1592 as a solely Protestant university and ordered that the Catholic [St. Patrick's](/wiki/St._Patrick%27s_Cathedral,_Dublin "St. Patrick's Cathedral, Dublin") and [Christ Church](/wiki/Christ_Church_Cathedral,_Dublin "Christ Church Cathedral, Dublin") cathedrals be converted to the Protestant church. The earliest map of the city of Dublin dates from 1610, and was by [John Speed](/wiki/John_Speed "John Speed").^[\[44\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMaxwell199756-57-46)^{#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMaxwell199756-57_46-0}

The city had a population of 21,000 in 1640 before a plague from 1649 to 1651 wiped out almost half of the inhabitants. However, the city prospered again soon after as a result of the wool and linen trade with England and reached a population of over 50,000 in 1700.^[\[45\]](#cite_note-47)^ By 1698 the manufacture of wool employed 12,000 people.^[\[46\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMaxwell1997252-48)^{#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMaxwell1997252_48-0}  

### Early modern {#Early_modern}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Early modern")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Henrietta_Street%2C_Dublin_D1.jpg/220px-Henrietta_Street%2C_Dublin_D1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Henrietta_Street,_Dublin_D1.jpg) [Henrietta Street](/wiki/Henrietta_Street,_Dublin "Henrietta Street, Dublin"), developed in the 1720s, is the earliest [Georgian street](/wiki/Georgian_Dublin "Georgian Dublin") in Dublin.

As the city continued to prosper during the 18th century, [Georgian Dublin](/wiki/Georgian_Dublin "Georgian Dublin") became, for a short period, the second-largest city of the [British Empire](/wiki/British_Empire "British Empire") and the fifth largest city in Europe, with the population exceeding 130,000. While some medieval streets and layouts (including the areas around [Temple Bar](/wiki/Temple_Bar,_Dublin "Temple Bar, Dublin"), Aungier Street, Capel Street and Thomas Street) were less affected by the wave of Georgian reconstruction, much of Dublin's architecture and layout dates from this period.^[\[47\]](#cite_note-49)^^[\[48\]](#cite_note-50)^^[\[49\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMaxwell1997220-51)^{#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMaxwell1997220_51-0}

Dublin grew even more dramatically during the 18th century, with the construction of many new districts and buildings, such as [Merrion Square](/wiki/Merrion_Square "Merrion Square"), [Parliament House](/wiki/Irish_Houses_of_Parliament "Irish Houses of Parliament") and the [Royal Exchange](/wiki/City_Hall,_Dublin "City Hall, Dublin"). The [Wide Streets Commission](/wiki/Wide_Streets_Commission "Wide Streets Commission") was established in 1757 at the request of [Dublin Corporation](/wiki/Dublin_Corporation "Dublin Corporation") to govern architectural standards on the layout of streets, bridges and buildings.^[\[50\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMaxwell199758-59-52)^ In 1759, the [Guinness brewery](/wiki/Guinness_brewery "Guinness brewery") was founded, and would eventually grow to become the largest brewery in the world and the largest employer in Dublin.^[\[51\]](#cite_note-53)^^[\[52\]](#cite_note-54)^ During the 1700s, linen was not subject to the same trade restrictions with England as wool, and became the most important Irish export. Over 1.5 million yards of linen was exported from Ireland in 1710, rising to almost 19 million yards by 1779.^[\[53\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMaxwell1997256-55)^{#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMaxwell1997256_55-0}  

### Late modern and contemporary {#Late_modern_and_contemporary}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Late modern and contemporary")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/General_Post_Office_Dublin_20060803.jpg/220px-General_Post_Office_Dublin_20060803.jpg)](/wiki/File:General_Post_Office_Dublin_20060803.jpg) [The GPO](/wiki/General_Post_Office_(Dublin) "General Post Office (Dublin)") on [O'Connell Street](/wiki/O%27Connell_Street "O'Connell Street") was at the centre of the 1916 [Easter Rising](/wiki/Easter_Rising "Easter Rising").

Dublin suffered a period of political and economic decline during the 19th century following the [Acts of Union 1800](/wiki/Acts_of_Union_1800 "Acts of Union 1800"), under which the seat of government was transferred to the [Westminster Parliament](/wiki/Parliament_of_the_United_Kingdom "Parliament of the United Kingdom") in London. The city played no major role in the [Industrial Revolution](/wiki/Industrial_Revolution "Industrial Revolution"), but remained the centre of administration and a transport hub for most of the island. Ireland had no significant sources of coal, the fuel of the time, and Dublin was not a centre of ship manufacturing, the other main driver of industrial development in Britain and Ireland.^[\[34\]](#cite_note-Davies-36)^ [Belfast](/wiki/Belfast "Belfast") developed faster than Dublin during this period on a mixture of international trade, factory-based linen cloth production and shipbuilding.^[\[54\]](#cite_note-Lyons-56)^ By 1814, the population of Dublin was 175,319 as counted under the Population Act, making the population of Dublin higher than any town in England except London.^[\[55\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMaxwell1997139-57)^{#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMaxwell1997139_57-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/The_shell_of_the_G.P.O._on_Sackville_Street_after_the_Easter_Rising_%286937669789%29.jpg/220px-The_shell_of_the_G.P.O._on_Sackville_Street_after_the_Easter_Rising_%286937669789%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:The_shell_of_the_G.P.O._on_Sackville_Street_after_the_Easter_Rising_(6937669789).jpg) Damage in Dublin city centre following the 1916 [Easter Rising](/wiki/Easter_Rising "Easter Rising") with the ruins of the GPO to the left

The [Easter Rising](/wiki/Easter_Rising "Easter Rising") of 1916, the [Irish War of Independence](/wiki/Irish_War_of_Independence "Irish War of Independence"), and the subsequent [Irish Civil War](/wiki/Irish_Civil_War "Irish Civil War") resulted in a significant amount of physical destruction in central Dublin. The [Government of the Irish Free State](/wiki/Government_of_the_Irish_Free_State "Government of the Irish Free State") rebuilt the city centre and located the new parliament, the [Oireachtas](/wiki/Oireachtas "Oireachtas"), in [Leinster House](/wiki/Leinster_House "Leinster House"). Since the beginning of [Norman](/wiki/Normans "Normans") rule in the 12th century, the city has functioned as the capital in varying geopolitical entities: [Lordship of Ireland](/wiki/Lordship_of_Ireland "Lordship of Ireland") (1171--1541), [Kingdom of Ireland](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Ireland "Kingdom of Ireland") (1541--1800), as part of the [United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland](/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland "United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland") (1801--1922), and the [Irish Republic](/wiki/Irish_Republic "Irish Republic") (1919--1922). Following the [partition of Ireland](/wiki/Partition_of_Ireland "Partition of Ireland") in 1922, it became the capital of the [Irish Free State](/wiki/Irish_Free_State "Irish Free State") (1922--1937) and now is the capital of Ireland. One of the memorials to commemorate that time is the [Garden of Remembrance](/wiki/Garden_of_Remembrance_(Dublin) "Garden of Remembrance (Dublin)").

Dublin was also a victim of the Northern Irish [Troubles](/wiki/The_Troubles "The Troubles"), although during this 30-year conflict, violence mainly occurred within Northern Ireland. A Loyalist paramilitary group, the [Ulster Volunteer Force](/wiki/Ulster_Volunteer_Force "Ulster Volunteer Force"), bombed the city during this time -- notably in an atrocity known as the [Dublin and Monaghan bombings](/wiki/Dublin_and_Monaghan_bombings "Dublin and Monaghan bombings") in which 34 people died, mainly in central Dublin.

Large parts of Georgian Dublin were demolished or substantially redeveloped in the mid-20th century during a boom in office building. After this boom, the recessions of the 1970s and 1980s slowed down the pace of building. Cumulatively, this led to a large decline in the number of people living in the centre of the city, and by 1985 the city had approximately 150 acres of derelict land which had been earmarked for development and 10 million square feet (900 thousand square metres) of office space.^[\[56\]](#cite_note-58)^{#cite_ref-58}

Since 1997, the landscape of Dublin has changed. The city was at the forefront of Ireland's economic expansion during the [Celtic Tiger](/wiki/Celtic_Tiger "Celtic Tiger") period, with private sector and state development of housing, transport and business. Following an economic decline during the Great Recession, Dublin has rebounded and as of 2017^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit)^ has close to full employment,^[\[57\]](#cite_note-:0-59)^ but has a significant problem with housing supply in both the city and surrounds.^[\[58\]](#cite_note-60)^{#cite_ref-60}  

Government {#Government}
------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Government")\]  

### Local {#Local}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Local")\]  
Further information: [Local government in Dublin](/wiki/Local_government_in_Dublin "Local government in Dublin")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Dublin_City_Council_Civic_Offices.JPG/220px-Dublin_City_Council_Civic_Offices.JPG)](/wiki/File:Dublin_City_Council_Civic_Offices.JPG) Civic Offices of [Dublin City Council](/wiki/Dublin_City_Council "Dublin City Council")

[Dublin City Council](/wiki/Dublin_City_Council "Dublin City Council") is a [unicameral](/wiki/Unicameral "Unicameral") assembly of 63 members elected every five years from [local electoral areas](/wiki/Local_electoral_area "Local electoral area").^[\[59\]](#cite_note-61)^ It is presided over by the [Lord Mayor](/wiki/Lord_Mayor_of_Dublin "Lord Mayor of Dublin"), who is elected for a yearly term and resides in Dublin's [Mansion House](/wiki/Mansion_House,_Dublin "Mansion House, Dublin"). Council meetings occur at [Dublin City Hall](/wiki/Dublin_City_Hall "Dublin City Hall"), while most of its administrative activities are based in the Civic Offices on [Wood Quay](/wiki/Wood_Quay "Wood Quay"). The party or coalition of parties with the majority of seats assigns committee members, introduces policies, and proposes the Lord Mayor. The Council passes an annual budget for spending on areas such as housing, traffic management, refuse, drainage, and planning. The Dublin City Manager is responsible for implementing City Council decisions but also has considerable executive power. Other neighbouring Dublin County Councils include [South Dublin County Council](/wiki/South_Dublin_County_Council "South Dublin County Council"), [Fingal County Council](/wiki/Fingal_County_Council "Fingal County Council") and [Dun Laoghaire-Rathdown County Council](/wiki/D%C3%BAn_Laoghaire%E2%80%93Rathdown_County_Council "Dún Laoghaire–Rathdown County Council").^[\[60\]](#cite_note-62)^{#cite_ref-62}  

### National {#National}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: National")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/20130810_dublin214.JPG/220px-20130810_dublin214.JPG)](/wiki/File:20130810_dublin214.JPG) [Leinster House](/wiki/Leinster_House "Leinster House") on Kildare Street houses the [Oireachtas](/wiki/Oireachtas "Oireachtas").

As the capital city, Dublin is the seat of the national parliament of Ireland, the [Oireachtas](/wiki/Oireachtas "Oireachtas"). It is composed of the [President of Ireland](/wiki/President_of_Ireland "President of Ireland"), [Dáil Éireann](/wiki/D%C3%A1il_%C3%89ireann "Dáil Éireann") as the house of representatives, and [Seanad Éireann](/wiki/Seanad_%C3%89ireann "Seanad Éireann") as the upper house. The President resides in [Áras an Uachtaráin](/wiki/%C3%81ras_an_Uachtar%C3%A1in "Áras an Uachtaráin") in [Phoenix Park](/wiki/Phoenix_Park "Phoenix Park"), while both houses of the Oireachtas meet in [Leinster House](/wiki/Leinster_House "Leinster House"), a former ducal residence on [Kildare Street](/wiki/Kildare_Street "Kildare Street"). It has been the home of the Irish parliament since the foundation of the [Irish Free State](/wiki/Irish_Free_State "Irish Free State") in 1922. The old [Irish Houses of Parliament](/wiki/Irish_Houses_of_Parliament "Irish Houses of Parliament") of the [Kingdom of Ireland](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Ireland "Kingdom of Ireland"), which dissolved in 1801, are located in [College Green](/wiki/College_Green,_Dublin "College Green, Dublin").

[Government Buildings](/wiki/Government_Buildings "Government Buildings") house the [Department of the Taoiseach](/wiki/Department_of_the_Taoiseach "Department of the Taoiseach"), the Council Chamber, the Department of Finance and the [Office of the Attorney General](/wiki/Attorney_General_of_Ireland "Attorney General of Ireland"). It consists of a main building (completed 1911) with two wings (completed 1921). It was designed by Thomas Manley Dean and Sir [Aston Webb](/wiki/Aston_Webb "Aston Webb") as the [Royal College of Science](/wiki/Royal_College_of_Science_(Ireland) "Royal College of Science (Ireland)"). The [First Dáil](/wiki/First_D%C3%A1il "First Dáil") originally met in the [Mansion House](/wiki/Mansion_House,_Dublin "Mansion House, Dublin") in 1919. The Irish Free State government took over the two wings of the building to serve as a temporary home for some ministries, while the central building became the College of Technology until 1989.^[\[61\]](#cite_note-63)^ Although both it and Leinster House were intended to be temporary locations, they became the permanent homes of parliament from then on.{#cite_ref-63}

For elections to [Dáil Éireann](/wiki/D%C3%A1il_%C3%89ireann "Dáil Éireann"), there are five constituencies that are wholly or predominantly in the Dublin City area: [Dublin Central](/wiki/Dublin_Central_(D%C3%A1il_constituency) "Dublin Central (Dáil constituency)") (4 seats), [Dublin Bay North](/wiki/Dublin_Bay_North_(D%C3%A1il_constituency) "Dublin Bay North (Dáil constituency)") (5 seats), [Dublin North-West](/wiki/Dublin_North-West_(D%C3%A1il_constituency) "Dublin North-West (Dáil constituency)") (3 seats), [Dublin South-Central](/wiki/Dublin_South-Central_(D%C3%A1il_constituency) "Dublin South-Central (Dáil constituency)") (4 seats) and [Dublin Bay South](/wiki/Dublin_Bay_South_(D%C3%A1il_constituency) "Dublin Bay South (Dáil constituency)") (4 seats). Twenty TDs are elected in total.^[\[62\]](#cite_note-64)^ The constituency of [Dublin West](/wiki/Dublin_West_(D%C3%A1il_constituency) "Dublin West (Dáil constituency)") (4 seats) is partially in Dublin City, but predominantly in [Fingal](/wiki/Fingal "Fingal").{#cite_ref-64}

At the [2024 general election](/wiki/2024_Irish_general_election "2024 Irish general election"), the Dublin city area elected 5 [Sinn Féin](/wiki/Sinn_F%C3%A9in "Sinn Féin"), 4 [Fianna Fáil](/wiki/Fianna_F%C3%A1il "Fianna Fáil"), 4 [Social Democrats](/wiki/Social_Democrats_(Ireland) "Social Democrats (Ireland)"), 3 [Fine Gael](/wiki/Fine_Gael "Fine Gael"), 2 [Labour](/wiki/Labour_Party_(Ireland) "Labour Party (Ireland)") and 2 Independents.^[\[63\]](#cite_note-65)^{#cite_ref-65}  

Geography {#Geography}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Geography")\]  

### Landscape {#Landscape}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Landscape")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Dublin_SPOT_1023.jpg/220px-Dublin_SPOT_1023.jpg)](/wiki/File:Dublin_SPOT_1023.jpg) Satellite image showing the [River Liffey](/wiki/River_Liffey "River Liffey") entering the [Irish Sea](/wiki/Irish_Sea "Irish Sea") as it divides Dublin into the [Northside](/wiki/Northside_(Dublin) "Northside (Dublin)") and the [Southside](/wiki/Southside_(Dublin) "Southside (Dublin)")

Dublin is situated at the mouth of the [River Liffey](/wiki/River_Liffey "River Liffey") and its urban area encompasses approximately 345 square kilometres (133 sq mi) in east-central Ireland. It is bordered by the Dublin Mountains, a low mountain range and sub range of the [Wicklow Mountains](/wiki/Wicklow_Mountains "Wicklow Mountains"), to the south and surrounded by flat farmland to the north and west.^[\[64\]](#cite_note-Facts_about_Dublin-66)^{#cite_ref-Facts_about_Dublin_66-0}  

#### Watercourses {#Watercourses}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Watercourses")\]  
See also: [List of rivers of County Dublin](/wiki/List_of_rivers_of_County_Dublin "List of rivers of County Dublin")

The River Liffey divides the city in two, between the Northside and the Southside. The Liffey bends at [Leixlip](/wiki/Leixlip "Leixlip") from a northeasterly route to a predominantly eastward direction, and this point also marks the transition to urban development from more agricultural land usage.^[\[65\]](#cite_note-erdb-67)^ The city itself was founded where the [River Poddle](/wiki/River_Poddle "River Poddle") met the Liffey, and the early Viking settlement was also facilitated by the small [Steine](/wiki/Steine_of_Dublin "Steine of Dublin") or Steyne River, the larger Camac^[\[66\]](#cite_note-LittleRvrs-Camac-68)^ and the Bradogue,^[\[67\]](#cite_note-LittleRvrs-Brad-69)^ in particular.{#cite_ref-LittleRvrs-Brad_69-0}

Two secondary rivers further divide the city: the [River Tolka](/wiki/River_Tolka "River Tolka"), running southeast into Dublin Bay, and the [River Dodder](/wiki/River_Dodder "River Dodder") running northeast to near the mouth of the Liffey, and these and the Liffey have multiple tributaries. A number of lesser rivers and streams also flow to the sea within the suburban parts of the city.^[\[68\]](#cite_note-TenDoz_rivers_sml_sea-70)^{#cite_ref-TenDoz_rivers_sml_sea_70-0}

Two canals -- the [Grand Canal](/wiki/Grand_Canal_of_Ireland "Grand Canal of Ireland") on the southside and the [Royal Canal](/wiki/Royal_Canal_of_Ireland "Royal Canal of Ireland") on the northside -- ring the inner city on their way from the west, both connecting with the [River Shannon](/wiki/River_Shannon "River Shannon").  

### Climate {#Climate}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Climate")\]

Similar to much of the rest of northwestern Europe, Dublin experiences a [maritime climate](/wiki/Maritime_climate "Maritime climate") ([*Cfb*](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate classification")) with mild-warm summers, cool winters, and a lack of temperature extremes. At [Merrion Square](/wiki/Merrion_Square "Merrion Square"), the coldest month is February, with an average minimum temperature of 4.1 °C (39.4 °F), and the warmest month is July, with an average maximum temperature of 20.1 °C (68.2 °F). Due to the [urban heat island](/wiki/Urban_heat_island "Urban heat island") effect, Dublin city has the warmest summertime nights in Ireland. The average minimum temperature at Merrion Square in July is 13.5 °C (56.3 °F), and the lowest July temperature ever recorded at the station was 7.8 °C (46.0 °F) on 3 July 1974.^[\[69\]](#cite_note-auto-71)^{#cite_ref-auto_71-0}

The highest temperature officially recorded in Dublin is 33.1 °C (91.6 °F) on 18 July 2022, at the [Phoenix Park](/wiki/Phoenix_Park "Phoenix Park"). A non-official record of 33.5 °C (92.3 °F) was also recorded at Phoenix Park in July 1876^[\[70\]](#cite_note-72)^{#cite_ref-72}

Dublin's sheltered location on the east coast makes it the driest place in Ireland, receiving only about half the rainfall of the west coast. [Ringsend](/wiki/Ringsend "Ringsend") in the south of the city records the lowest rainfall in the country, with an average annual precipitation of 683 mm (27 in),^[\[71\]](#cite_note-73)^ with the average annual precipitation in the city centre being 726 mm (29 in). At Merrion Square, the wettest year and driest year on record occurred within 5 years of each other, with 1953 receiving just 463.1 mm (18.23 in) of rainfall, while 1958 recorded 1,022.5 mm (40.26 in).^[\[69\]](#cite_note-auto-71)^ The main precipitation in winter is rain; however snow showers do occur between November and March. Hail is more common than snow. Strong Atlantic winds are most common in autumn. These winds can affect Dublin, but due to its easterly location, it is least affected compared to other parts of the country. However, in winter, easterly winds render the city colder and more prone to snow showers.{#cite_ref-auto_71-1}

The city experiences long summer days and short winter days. Based on satellite observations, [Met Éireann](/wiki/Met_%C3%89ireann "Met Éireann") estimates that Dublin's coastal areas typically receive over 1,600 hours of sunshine per year,^[\[72\]](#cite_note-74)^ with the climate getting progressively duller inland. Dublin airport, located north of city and about 10 kilometres (6.2 mi) from the coast, records an average of 1,485 hours of sunshine per year. The station at Dublin airport has been maintaining climate records since November 1941. The sunniest year on record was 1,740 hours in 1959, and the dullest year was 1987 with 1,240 hours of sunshine. The lowest amount of monthly sunshine on record was 16.4 hours in January 1996, while the highest was 305.9 hours in July 1955.^[\[73\]](#cite_note-75)^{#cite_ref-75}

In the 20th century, smog and air-pollution were an issue in the city, precipitating a ban on bituminous fuels across Dublin.^[\[74\]](#cite_note-coalbangov-76)^^[\[75\]](#cite_note-coalbantimes-77)^ The ban was implemented in 1990 to address black smoke concentrations, that had been linked to cardiovascular and respiratory deaths in residents. Since the ban, non-trauma death rates, respiratory death rates and cardiovascular death rates have declined -- by an estimated 350 deaths annually.^[\[76\]](#cite_note-78)^^[\[75\]](#cite_note-coalbantimes-77)^{#cite_ref-coalbantimes_77-1}

Cityscape {#Cityscape}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: Cityscape")\]  

### Areas {#Areas}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Areas")\]  

#### City centre {#City_centre}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: City centre")\]

The historic city centre of Dublin is encircled by the [Royal Canal](/wiki/Royal_Canal "Royal Canal") and [Grand Canal](/wiki/Grand_Canal_(Ireland) "Grand Canal (Ireland)"), bounded to the west by [Heuston railway station](/wiki/Heuston_railway_station "Heuston railway station") and [Phoenix Park](/wiki/Phoenix_Park "Phoenix Park"), and to the east by the [IFSC](/wiki/International_Financial_Services_Centre,_Dublin "International Financial Services Centre, Dublin") and the [Docklands](/wiki/Dublin_Docklands "Dublin Docklands"). [O'Connell Street](/wiki/O%27Connell_Street "O'Connell Street") is the main thoroughfare of the inner city and many Dublin Bus routes, as well as the Green line of the [Luas](/wiki/Luas "Luas"), have a stop at O'Connell Street. The main shopping streets of the inner city include [Henry Street](/wiki/Henry_Street,_Dublin "Henry Street, Dublin") on the Northside, and [Grafton Street](/wiki/Grafton_Street "Grafton Street") on the Southside.^[\[85\]](#cite_note-89)^^[\[86\]](#cite_note-90)^{#cite_ref-90}
[![Victorian Buildings on South Great George's Street, Dublin](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/South_Great_George%27s_Street_Dublin.jpg/220px-South_Great_George%27s_Street_Dublin.jpg)](/wiki/File:South_Great_George%27s_Street_Dublin.jpg) Victorian-era buildings, such as the [George's Street Arcade](/wiki/George%27s_Street_Arcade "George's Street Arcade"), are common in the south inner city.

In some tourism and real-estate marketing contexts, inner Dublin is sometimes divided into a number of quarters.^[\[87\]](#cite_note-quartersvisit-91)^^[\[88\]](#cite_note-92)^ These include the Medieval Quarter (in the area of [Dublin Castle](/wiki/Dublin_Castle "Dublin Castle"), [Christ Church](/wiki/Christ_Church,_Dublin "Christ Church, Dublin") and [St Patrick's Cathedral](/wiki/St_Patrick%27s_Cathedral,_Dublin "St Patrick's Cathedral, Dublin") and the old city walls),^[\[89\]](#cite_note-93)^ the Georgian Quarter (including the area around St Stephen's Green, Trinity College, and [Merrion Square](/wiki/Merrion_Square "Merrion Square")), the Docklands Quarter (around the [Dublin Docklands](/wiki/Dublin_Docklands "Dublin Docklands") and [Silicon Docks](/wiki/Silicon_Docks "Silicon Docks")), the Cultural Quarter (around [Temple Bar](/wiki/Temple_Bar,_Dublin "Temple Bar, Dublin")), and Creative Quarter (between South William Street and George's Street).^[\[90\]](#cite_note-94)^{#cite_ref-94}  

#### Suburbs {#Suburbs}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: Suburbs")\]
[![Apartment blocks in Sandyford, Dublin](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Sandyford_apts_1.jpg/220px-Sandyford_apts_1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sandyford_apts_1.jpg) High density apartments in [Sandyford](/wiki/Sandyford,_Dublin "Sandyford, Dublin")

Dublin has dozens of suburbs; northside suburbs include [Blanchardstown](/wiki/Blanchardstown "Blanchardstown"), [Finglas](/wiki/Finglas "Finglas"), [Ballymun](/wiki/Ballymun "Ballymun"), [Clontarf](/wiki/Clontarf,_Dublin "Clontarf, Dublin"), [Raheny](/wiki/Raheny "Raheny"), [Malahide](/wiki/Malahide "Malahide") and [Howth](/wiki/Howth "Howth"), while southside suburbs include [Tallaght](/wiki/Tallaght "Tallaght"), [Sandyford](/wiki/Sandyford,_Dublin "Sandyford, Dublin"), [Templeogue](/wiki/Templeogue "Templeogue"), [Drimnagh](/wiki/Drimnagh "Drimnagh"), [Rathmines](/wiki/Rathmines "Rathmines"), [Dún Laoghaire](/wiki/D%C3%BAn_Laoghaire "Dún Laoghaire") and [Dalkey](/wiki/Dalkey "Dalkey").

Starting in the late 2010s, there was a significant amount of high density residential developments in the suburbs of Dublin,^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ with mid to high-rise apartments being built in Sandyford,^[\[91\]](#cite_note-aidanmurphy-95)^ [Ashtown](/wiki/Ashtown,_Dublin "Ashtown, Dublin"),^[\[92\]](#cite_note-ronaldquinlan-96)^ and Tallaght.^[\[93\]](#cite_note-97)^{#cite_ref-97}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Dublin_-_Molly_Malone.jpg/220px-Dublin_-_Molly_Malone.jpg)](/wiki/File:Dublin_-_Molly_Malone.jpg) [Molly Malone](/wiki/Molly_Malone "Molly Malone") statue  

### Cultural divide {#Cultural_divide}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section: Cultural divide")\]

A north--south division once, to some extent, traditionally existed, with the River Liffey as the divider.^[\[94\]](#cite_note-northsouthmyth2-98)^ The southside was, in recent times, generally seen as being more affluent and genteel than the northside.^[\[94\]](#cite_note-northsouthmyth2-98)^ There have also been some social divisions evident between the coastal suburbs in the east of the city, and the newer developments further to the west.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^{#cite_ref-northsouthmyth2_98-1}  

### Landmarks {#Landmarks}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: Landmarks")\]  
Further information: [List of public art in Dublin](/wiki/List_of_public_art_in_Dublin "List of public art in Dublin")

Dublin has many landmarks and monuments dating back hundreds of years. One of the oldest is [Dublin Castle](/wiki/Dublin_Castle "Dublin Castle"), which was first founded as a major defensive work on the orders of England's [King John](/wiki/John,_King_of_England "John, King of England") in 1204, shortly after the [Norman invasion of Ireland](/wiki/Norman_invasion_of_Ireland "Norman invasion of Ireland") in 1169, when it was commanded that a castle be built with strong walls and good ditches for the defence of the city, the administration of justice, and the protection of the King's treasure.^[\[95\]](#cite_note-history-99)^ Largely complete by 1230, the castle was of typical Norman courtyard design, with a central square without a [keep](/wiki/Keep "Keep"), bounded on all sides by tall defensive walls and protected at each corner by a circular tower. Sited to the south-east of Norman Dublin, the castle formed one corner of the outer perimeter of the city, using the [River Poddle](/wiki/River_Poddle "River Poddle") as a natural means of defence.{#cite_ref-history_99-0}

One of Dublin's most prominent landmarks is the [Spire of Dublin](/wiki/Spire_of_Dublin "Spire of Dublin"), officially entitled the "Monument of Light".^[\[96\]](#cite_note-100)^ It is a 121.2-metre (398 ft) conical spire made of stainless steel, completed in 2003 and located on [O'Connell Street](/wiki/O%27Connell_Street "O'Connell Street"), where it meets Henry Street and North Earl Street. It replaced [Nelson's Pillar](/wiki/Nelson%27s_Pillar "Nelson's Pillar") and is intended to mark Dublin's place in the 21st century. The spire was designed by [Ian Ritchie Architects](/wiki/Ian_Ritchie_Architects "Ian Ritchie Architects"),^[\[97\]](#cite_note-101)^ who sought an "Elegant and dynamic simplicity bridging art and technology". The base of the monument is lit and the top is illuminated to provide a beacon in the night sky across the city.{#cite_ref-101}

The Old Library of [Trinity College Dublin](/wiki/Trinity_College_Dublin "Trinity College Dublin"), holding the [Book of Kells](/wiki/Book_of_Kells "Book of Kells"), is one of the city's most visited sites.^[\[98\]](#cite_note-102)^ The Book of Kells is an illustrated manuscript created by Irish monks circa 800 AD. The [Ha'penny Bridge](/wiki/Ha%27penny_Bridge "Ha'penny Bridge"), an iron footbridge over the River Liffey, is one of the most photographed sights in Dublin and is considered to be one of Dublin's most iconic landmarks.^[\[99\]](#cite_note-103)^{#cite_ref-103}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/O%27Connell_Street_Dublin_%26_Jim_Larkin.JPG/170px-O%27Connell_Street_Dublin_%26_Jim_Larkin.JPG)](/wiki/File:O%27Connell_Street_Dublin_%26_Jim_Larkin.JPG) The [Spire of Dublin](/wiki/Spire_of_Dublin "Spire of Dublin") rises behind the statue of [Jim Larkin](/wiki/James_Larkin "James Larkin").

Other landmarks and monuments include [Christ Church Cathedral](/wiki/Christ_Church_Cathedral,_Dublin "Christ Church Cathedral, Dublin") and [St Patrick's Cathedral](/wiki/St_Patrick%27s_Cathedral,_Dublin "St Patrick's Cathedral, Dublin"), the [Mansion House](/wiki/Mansion_House,_Dublin "Mansion House, Dublin"), the [Molly Malone](/wiki/Molly_Malone "Molly Malone") statue, the complex of buildings around Leinster House, including part of the [National Museum of Ireland](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Ireland "National Museum of Ireland") and the [National Library of Ireland](/wiki/National_Library_of_Ireland "National Library of Ireland"), [The Custom House](/wiki/The_Custom_House "The Custom House") and [Áras an Uachtaráin](/wiki/%C3%81ras_an_Uachtar%C3%A1in "Áras an Uachtaráin"). Other sights include the [Anna Livia monument](/wiki/Anna_Livia_(monument) "Anna Livia (monument)"). The [Poolbeg Towers](/wiki/Poolbeg_Generating_Station "Poolbeg Generating Station") are also landmark features of Dublin, and visible from various spots around the city.  

### Parks {#Parks}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: Parks")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Dublin_Stephen%27s_Green-44_edit.jpg/220px-Dublin_Stephen%27s_Green-44_edit.jpg)](/wiki/File:Dublin_Stephen%27s_Green-44_edit.jpg) Aerial view of [St Stephen's Green](/wiki/St_Stephen%27s_Green "St Stephen's Green")

There are 302 parks and 66 green spaces within the [Dublin City Council](/wiki/Dublin_City_Council "Dublin City Council") area as of 2018,^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ with the council managing over 1,500 hectares (3,700 acres) of parks.^[\[100\]](#cite_note-104)^ Public parks include the [Phoenix Park](/wiki/Phoenix_Park "Phoenix Park"), [Herbert Park](/wiki/Herbert_Park "Herbert Park"), [St Stephen's Green](/wiki/St_Stephen%27s_Green "St Stephen's Green"), [Saint Anne's Park](/wiki/Saint_Anne%27s_Park "Saint Anne's Park") and [Bull Island](/wiki/Bull_Island "Bull Island"). The Phoenix Park is about 3 km (2 miles) west of the city centre, north of the [River Liffey](/wiki/River_Liffey "River Liffey"). Its 16-kilometre (10 mi) perimeter wall encloses 707 hectares (1,750 acres), making it one of the largest walled city parks in Europe.^[\[101\]](#cite_note-105)^ It includes large areas of grassland and tree-lined avenues, and since the 17th century has been home to a herd of wild [fallow deer](/wiki/Fallow_deer "Fallow deer"). The residence of the [President of Ireland](/wiki/President_of_Ireland "President of Ireland") (Áras an Uachtaráin), which was built in 1751,^[\[102\]](#cite_note-106)^ is located in the park. The park is also home to [Dublin Zoo](/wiki/Dublin_Zoo "Dublin Zoo"), [Ashtown Castle](/wiki/Ashtown_Castle "Ashtown Castle"), and the official residence of the [United States Ambassador](/wiki/United_States_Ambassador_to_Ireland "United States Ambassador to Ireland"). Music concerts are also sometimes held in the park.{#cite_ref-106}

St Stephen's Green is adjacent to one of Dublin's main shopping streets, [Grafton Street](/wiki/Grafton_Street,_Dublin "Grafton Street, Dublin"), and to [a shopping centre named after it](/wiki/Stephen%27s_Green_Shopping_Centre "Stephen's Green Shopping Centre"), while on its surrounding streets are the offices of a number of public bodies.

[Saint Anne's Park](/wiki/Saint_Anne%27s_Park "Saint Anne's Park") is a public park and recreational facility, shared between [Raheny](/wiki/Raheny "Raheny") and [Clontarf](/wiki/Clontarf,_Dublin "Clontarf, Dublin"), both suburbs on the Northside. The park, the second largest municipal park in Dublin, is part of a former 2-square-kilometre (0.8 sq mi; 500-acre) estate assembled by members of the [Guinness family](/wiki/Guinness_family "Guinness family"), beginning with [Benjamin Lee Guinness](/wiki/Benjamin_Lee_Guinness "Benjamin Lee Guinness") in 1835. The largest municipal park is adjacent (North) [Bull Island](/wiki/Bull_Island "Bull Island"), also shared between Clontarf and Raheny, featuring a 5 km beach, Dollymount Strand.  

### City boundaries {#City_boundaries}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=20 "Edit section: City boundaries")\]

From 1842, the boundaries of the city were comprehended by the [baronies](/wiki/Barony_(Ireland) "Barony (Ireland)") of Dublin City and the barony of [Dublin](/wiki/Dublin_(barony) "Dublin (barony)"). Over time, the city has absorbed area previously administered as part of County Dublin (now the three counties of Dún Laoghaire--Rathdown, Fingal and South Dublin), with a change in 1985 also returning areas to the county.

Economy {#Economy}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=21 "Edit section: Economy")\]  
Main article: [Economy of Dublin](/wiki/Economy_of_Dublin "Economy of Dublin")  
See also: [Economy of County Dublin](/wiki/County_Dublin#Economy "County Dublin")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/The_Ulster_Bank_Group_HQ%2C_George%27s_Quay_Plaza_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1743476.jpg/220px-The_Ulster_Bank_Group_HQ%2C_George%27s_Quay_Plaza_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1743476.jpg)](/wiki/File:The_Ulster_Bank_Group_HQ,_George%27s_Quay_Plaza_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1743476.jpg) [Ulster Bank](/wiki/Ulster_Bank "Ulster Bank") on [George's Quay Plaza](/wiki/George%27s_Quay_Plaza "George's Quay Plaza")

The Dublin region is the economic centre of Ireland, and was at the forefront of the country's economic expansion during the [Celtic Tiger](/wiki/Celtic_Tiger "Celtic Tiger") period. In 2009, Dublin was listed as the fourth richest city in the world by [purchasing power](/wiki/Purchasing_power "Purchasing power") and 10th richest by personal income.^[\[111\]](#cite_note-115)^^[\[112\]](#cite_note-116)^ According to *Mercer's 2011 Worldwide Cost of Living Survey* , Dublin was the 13th most expensive city in the [European Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union") (down from 10th in 2010) and the 58th most expensive place to live in the world (down from 42nd in 2010).^[\[113\]](#cite_note-117)^ As of 2017^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit)^, approximately 874,400 people were employed in the [Greater Dublin Area](/wiki/Greater_Dublin_Area "Greater Dublin Area"). Around 60% of people who are employed in Ireland's financial, ICT, and professional sectors are located in this area.^[\[114\]](#cite_note-118)^{#cite_ref-118}

A number of Dublin's traditional industries, such as food processing, textile manufacturing, brewing, and distilling have gradually declined, although [Guinness](/wiki/Guinness "Guinness") has been brewed at the [St. James's Gate Brewery](/wiki/St._James%27s_Gate_Brewery "St. James's Gate Brewery") since 1759. Economic improvements in the 1990s attracted a number of global pharmaceutical, information and communications technology companies to the city and Greater Dublin Area. Companies such as [Microsoft](/wiki/Microsoft "Microsoft"), [Google](/wiki/Google "Google"), [Amazon](/wiki/Amazon.com "Amazon.com"), [eBay](/wiki/EBay "EBay"), [PayPal](/wiki/PayPal "PayPal"), [Yahoo!](/wiki/Yahoo! "Yahoo!"), [Facebook](/wiki/Facebook "Facebook"), [X](/wiki/Twitter "Twitter"), [Accenture](/wiki/Accenture "Accenture"), [TikTok](/wiki/TikTok "TikTok") and [Pfizer](/wiki/Pfizer "Pfizer") now have European headquarters or operational bases in the city with several located in enterprise clusters like the [Digital Hub](/wiki/The_Digital_Hub "The Digital Hub") and [Silicon Docks](/wiki/Silicon_Docks "Silicon Docks"). The presence of these companies has driven economic expansion in the city and led to Dublin sometimes being referred to as the "Tech Capital of Europe".^[\[57\]](#cite_note-:0-59)^{#cite_ref-:0_59-1}

Financial services have also become important to the city since the establishment of Dublin's [International Financial Services Centre](/wiki/International_Financial_Services_Centre,_Dublin "International Financial Services Centre, Dublin") in 1987. More than 500 operations are approved to trade under the IFSC programme. The centre is host to half of the world's top 50 banks and to half of the top 20 insurance companies.^[\[115\]](#cite_note-119)^ Many international firms have established major headquarters in the city, such as [Citibank](/wiki/Citibank "Citibank"). The [Irish Stock Exchange](/wiki/Irish_Stock_Exchange "Irish Stock Exchange") (ISEQ), [Internet Neutral Exchange](/wiki/Internet_Neutral_Exchange "Internet Neutral Exchange") (INEX) and Irish Enterprise Exchange (IEX) are also located in Dublin. Dublin has been positioned as one of the main cities vying to host Financial Services companies hoping to retain access to the Eurozone after [Brexit](/wiki/Brexit "Brexit"). The Celtic Tiger also led to a temporary boom in construction, with large redevelopment projects in the [Dublin Docklands](/wiki/Dublin_Docklands "Dublin Docklands") and [Spencer Dock](/wiki/Spencer_Dock "Spencer Dock"). Completed projects include the [Convention Centre](/wiki/Convention_Centre_Dublin "Convention Centre Dublin"), the [3Arena](/wiki/3Arena "3Arena"), and the [Bord Gáis Energy Theatre](/wiki/Bord_G%C3%A1is_Energy_Theatre "Bord Gáis Energy Theatre").{#cite_ref-119}

In the second quarter of 2018, Dublin touched its lowest unemployment rate in a decade, when it fell down to 5.7% as reported by the Dublin Economic Monitor.^[\[116\]](#cite_note-120)^^[\[117\]](#cite_note-121)^ In November 2022, Dublin was ranked as one of the worst cities in the world for travel, health and cost of living.^[\[118\]](#cite_note-122)^ On 24 September 2022, thousands took to the streets in protest against the cost of living crisis.^[\[119\]](#cite_note-123)^{#cite_ref-123}

As of 2024, the [Gross Domestic Product](/wiki/Gross_domestic_product "Gross domestic product") of Dublin is €253.6 billion, meaning it has one of the biggest city economies in the [European Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union").  

Transport {#Transport}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=22 "Edit section: Transport")\]  
Main article: [Transport in Dublin](/wiki/Transport_in_Dublin "Transport in Dublin")  

### Road {#Road}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=23 "Edit section: Road")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/DublinM50.png/220px-DublinM50.png)](/wiki/File:DublinM50.png) The [M50 motorway](/wiki/M50_motorway_(Ireland) "M50 motorway (Ireland)") surrounding Dublin

The road network in Ireland is primarily focused on Dublin. The [M50 motorway](/wiki/M50_motorway_(Ireland) "M50 motorway (Ireland)"), a semi-[ring road](/wiki/Ring_road "Ring road") which runs around the south, west and north of the city, connects important national primary routes to the rest of the country. In 2008, the [West-Link](/wiki/West-Link "West-Link") toll bridge was replaced by the [eFlow](/wiki/EFlow "EFlow") barrier-free tolling system, with a three-tiered charge system based on electronic tags and car pre-registration.^[\[120\]](#cite_note-124)^{#cite_ref-124}

The first phase of a proposed eastern bypass for the city is the [Dublin Port Tunnel](/wiki/Dublin_Port_Tunnel "Dublin Port Tunnel"), which officially opened in 2006 to mainly cater for heavy vehicles. The tunnel connects [Dublin Port](/wiki/Dublin_Port "Dublin Port") and the [M1 motorway](/wiki/M1_motorway_(Republic_of_Ireland) "M1 motorway (Republic of Ireland)") close to Dublin Airport. The city is also surrounded by an inner and outer orbital route. The inner orbital route runs approximately around the heart of the Georgian city and the outer orbital route runs primarily along the natural circle formed by Dublin's two canals, the [Grand Canal](/wiki/Grand_Canal_of_Ireland "Grand Canal of Ireland") and the [Royal Canal](/wiki/Royal_Canal_of_Ireland "Royal Canal of Ireland"), as well as the North and South Circular Roads.

The 2016 [TomTom](/wiki/TomTom "TomTom") Traffic Index ranked Dublin the 15th most congested city in the world and the 7th most congested in Europe.^[\[121\]](#cite_note-125)^^[\[122\]](#cite_note-126)^{#cite_ref-126}  

#### Bus {#Bus}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=24 "Edit section: Bus")\]

Dublin is served by a network of nearly 200 bus routes which cover the city and suburbs. The majority of these are provided by [Dublin Bus](/wiki/Dublin_Bus "Dublin Bus"), with a modest number having been transferred to Go Ahead Ireland in 2018. A number of smaller companies also operate. Fares are generally calculated on a stage system based on distance travelled. There are several different levels of fares, which apply on most services. A "Real Time Passenger Information" system was introduced at Dublin Bus bus stops in 2012 in which signs relay display the projected time of the next buses' arrival based on its GPS position. The [National Transport Authority](/wiki/National_Transport_Authority_(Ireland) "National Transport Authority (Ireland)") is responsible for integration of bus and rail services in Dublin and has been involved in introducing a pre-paid smart card, called a [TFI Leap Card](/wiki/TFI_Leap_Card "TFI Leap Card"), which can be used on all of Dublin's public transport services.^[\[123\]](#cite_note-127)^{#cite_ref-127}

The [BusConnects](/wiki/BusConnects "BusConnects") programme includes a number of proposed improvements to Dublin's bus network, including new spine and orbital routes. The spine routes are intended to increase the frequency of buses along major corridors, and the orbital routes aim to "provide connections between suburbs and town centres, without having to travel into the City Centre".^[\[124\]](#cite_note-128)^ In 2022, Dublin Bus began the process of electrifying its fleet with new [battery-powered buses](/wiki/Battery_electric_bus "Battery electric bus"), with plans for 85% of Dublin buses to be zero-emission by 2032.^[\[125\]](#cite_note-129)^{#cite_ref-129}  

#### Cycling {#Cycling}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=25 "Edit section: Cycling")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Dublin_Bikes.jpg/220px-Dublin_Bikes.jpg)](/wiki/File:Dublin_Bikes.jpg) [Dublinbikes](/wiki/Dublinbikes "Dublinbikes") terminal in the [Docklands](/wiki/Dublin_Docklands "Dublin Docklands")

The [2011 census](/wiki/2011_census_of_Ireland "2011 census of Ireland") indicated that 5.9% of commuters in Dublin cycled. A 2013 report by Dublin City Council on traffic flows crossing the canals in and out of the city found that just under 10% of all traffic was made up of cyclists, representing an increase of 14.1% over 2012 and an 87.2% increase over 2006 levels. The increase was attributed to measures such as the Dublinbikes bike rental scheme, the provision of cycle lanes, public awareness campaigns to promote cycling and the introduction of the 30 km/h city centre speed limit.^[\[126\]](#cite_note-130)^{#cite_ref-130}

Dublin City Council began installing cycle lanes and tracks throughout the city in the 1990s, and as of 2012^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit)^ the city had over 200 kilometres (120 miles) of specific on- and off-road tracks for cyclists.^[\[127\]](#cite_note-131)^ In 2011, the city was ranked 9th of major world cities on the *Copenhagenize Index of Bicycle-Friendly Cities* .^[\[128\]](#cite_note-132)^ The same index showed a fall to 15th in 2015,^[\[129\]](#cite_note-133)^ and Dublin was outside the top 20 in 2017.^[\[130\]](#cite_note-134)^{#cite_ref-134}

[Dublinbikes](/wiki/Dublinbikes "Dublinbikes") is a [self-service bicycle rental scheme](/wiki/Bicycle_sharing_system "Bicycle sharing system") which has been in operation in Dublin since 2009. Sponsored by [JCDecaux](/wiki/JCDecaux "JCDecaux") and [Just Eat](/wiki/Just_Eat "Just Eat"), the scheme consists of hundreds of unisex bicycles stationed at 44 terminals throughout the city centre. Users must make a subscription for either an annual Long Term Hire Card or purchase a three-day ticket.^[\[131\]](#cite_note-135)^ As of 2018^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit)^, Dublinbikes had over 66,000 long-term subscribers making over 2 million journeys per year.^[\[132\]](#cite_note-136)^^[\[133\]](#cite_note-137)^{#cite_ref-137}  

### Rail {#Rail}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=26 "Edit section: Rail")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/LUAS_trams_at_Tallaght_terminus._-_geograph.org.uk_-_1387090.jpg/220px-LUAS_trams_at_Tallaght_terminus._-_geograph.org.uk_-_1387090.jpg)](/wiki/File:LUAS_trams_at_Tallaght_terminus._-_geograph.org.uk_-_1387090.jpg) [Luas](/wiki/Luas "Luas") trams at the [Tallaght](/wiki/Tallaght "Tallaght") terminus

[Heuston](/wiki/Dublin_Heuston_railway_station "Dublin Heuston railway station") and [Connolly](/wiki/Dublin_Connolly_railway_station "Dublin Connolly railway station") stations are the two main railway termini in Dublin. Operated by [Iarnród Éireann](/wiki/Iarnr%C3%B3d_%C3%89ireann "Iarnród Éireann"), the [Dublin Suburban Rail](/wiki/Dublin_Suburban_Rail "Dublin Suburban Rail") network consists of five railway lines serving the Greater Dublin Area and commuter towns such as [Drogheda](/wiki/Drogheda "Drogheda") and [Dundalk](/wiki/Dundalk "Dundalk") in County Louth, [Gorey](/wiki/Gorey "Gorey") in [County Wexford](/wiki/County_Wexford "County Wexford"), and extending as far as [Portlaoise](/wiki/Portlaoise "Portlaoise") in County Laois, and once a day to [Newry](/wiki/Newry "Newry"). One of the five lines is the electrified [Dublin Area Rapid Transit](/wiki/Dublin_Area_Rapid_Transit "Dublin Area Rapid Transit") (DART) line, which runs primarily along the coast of Dublin, comprising 31 stations, from [Malahide](/wiki/Malahide "Malahide") and [Howth](/wiki/Howth "Howth") southwards as far as [Bray](/wiki/Bray,_County_Wicklow "Bray, County Wicklow") and [Greystones](/wiki/Greystones "Greystones") in County Wicklow.^[\[134\]](#cite_note-138)^ [Commuter rail](/wiki/Commuter_(Irish_Rail) "Commuter (Irish Rail)") operates on the other four lines using Irish Rail [diesel multiple units](/wiki/Diesel_multiple_unit "Diesel multiple unit"). In 2013, passengers for DART and Dublin Suburban lines were 16 million and 11.7 million, respectively (around 75% of all Irish Rail passengers).^[\[135\]](#cite_note-139)^{#cite_ref-139}

Dublin once had an extensive system of [trams](/wiki/Dublin_tramways "Dublin tramways") but this was largely phased out by 1949. A new [light rail](/wiki/Light_rail "Light rail") system, often described as a tram system, the [Luas](/wiki/Luas "Luas"), was launched in 2004, and is run by [Transdev](/wiki/Transdev "Transdev") Ireland (under contract from [Transport Infrastructure Ireland](/wiki/Transport_Infrastructure_Ireland "Transport Infrastructure Ireland")), carrying over 34 million passengers annually.^[\[136\]](#cite_note-Luas_-_Frequently_Asked_Questions-140)^ The network consists of two interconnecting lines; the [Red Line](/wiki/Red_Line_(Luas) "Red Line (Luas)") links the [Docklands](/wiki/Dublin_Docklands "Dublin Docklands") and city centre with the south-western suburbs of [Tallaght](/wiki/Tallaght "Tallaght") and [Saggart](/wiki/Saggart "Saggart"), while the [Green Line](/wiki/Green_Line_(Luas) "Green Line (Luas)") connects northern inner city suburbs and the main city centre with suburbs to the south of the city including [Sandyford](/wiki/Sandyford "Sandyford") and [Brides Glen](/wiki/Brides_Glen_Luas_stop "Brides Glen Luas stop"), mostly along the former route of the [Harcourt Street railway line](/wiki/Harcourt_Street_railway_line "Harcourt Street railway line"). Together these lines comprise a total 67 stops and 44.5 kilometres (27.7 mi) of track.^[\[136\]](#cite_note-Luas_-_Frequently_Asked_Questions-140)^ Construction of a 6 km extension to the Green Line, bringing it into the north of the city, commenced in June 2013 and was opened for passenger travel on 9 December 2017.^[\[137\]](#cite_note-141)^{#cite_ref-141}

A [metro](/wiki/Rapid_transit "Rapid transit") service is proposed under the name of [Metrolink](/wiki/MetroLink_(Dublin) "MetroLink (Dublin)"), and planned to run from Dublin's [northside](/wiki/Northside,_Dublin "Northside, Dublin") to [Charlemont](/wiki/Charlemont_Luas_stop "Charlemont Luas stop") via [Dublin Airport](/wiki/Dublin_Airport "Dublin Airport") and [St. Stephen's Green](/wiki/St._Stephen%27s_Green "St. Stephen's Green").^[\[138\]](#cite_note-142)^{#cite_ref-142}  

### Rail and ferry {#Rail_and_ferry}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=27 "Edit section: Rail and ferry")\]

[Dublin Connolly](/wiki/Dublin_Connolly "Dublin Connolly") is connected by bus to [Dublin Port](/wiki/Dublin_Port "Dublin Port") and ferries run by [Irish Ferries](/wiki/Irish_Ferries "Irish Ferries") and [Stena Line](/wiki/Stena_Line "Stena Line") to [Holyhead](/wiki/Holyhead_railway_station "Holyhead railway station") for connecting trains on the [North Wales Coast Line](/wiki/North_Wales_Coast_Line "North Wales Coast Line") to [Chester](/wiki/Chester_railway_station "Chester railway station"), [Crewe](/wiki/Crewe_railway_station "Crewe railway station") and [London Euston](/wiki/Euston_railway_station "Euston railway station"). [Dublin Connolly](/wiki/Dublin_Connolly "Dublin Connolly") to Dublin Port can be reached via [Amiens Street, Dublin](/wiki/Amiens_Street,_Dublin "Amiens Street, Dublin") into [Store Street](/wiki/Store_Street "Store Street") or by Luas via [Busáras](/wiki/Bus%C3%A1ras "Busáras") where [Dublin Bus](/wiki/Dublin_Bus "Dublin Bus") operates services to the Ferry Terminal.^[\[139\]](#cite_note-143)^{#cite_ref-143}  

### Air {#Air}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=28 "Edit section: Air")\]  

#### Dublin Airport {#Dublin_Airport}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=29 "Edit section: Dublin Airport")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/T2Dublin_Airport-doyler79.jpg/220px-T2Dublin_Airport-doyler79.jpg)](/wiki/File:T2Dublin_Airport-doyler79.jpg) [Dublin Airport](/wiki/Dublin_Airport "Dublin Airport")

[Dublin Airport](/wiki/Dublin_Airport "Dublin Airport") (owned and operated by [DAA](/wiki/DAA_(Irish_company) "DAA (Irish company)")) is located north of Dublin city, near [Swords](/wiki/Swords,_Dublin "Swords, Dublin") in the administrative county of [Fingal](/wiki/Fingal "Fingal"). The headquarters of Ireland's flag carrier [Aer Lingus](/wiki/Aer_Lingus "Aer Lingus") and regional airline [CityJet](/wiki/CityJet "CityJet") are located there, and those of low-cost carrier [Ryanair](/wiki/Ryanair "Ryanair") nearby. The airport offers a short and medium-haul network, domestic services to regional airports in Ireland, and long-haul services to the United States, Canada, the Middle East and Hong Kong. Dublin Airport is the 11th busiest in the European Union,^[\[140\]](#cite_note-144)^ and by far the busiest airport on the island of Ireland.{#cite_ref-144}

In 2015 and 2016, transatlantic traffic grew, with 158 summer flights a week to North America, making it the sixth largest European hub for that route over the year.^[\[141\]](#cite_note-145)^ Transatlantic traffic was also the fastest-growing segment of the market for the airport in 2016, in which a 16% increase from 2015 brought the yearly number of passengers travelling between Dublin and North America to 2.9 million.^[\[142\]](#cite_note-dub2016record-146)^{#cite_ref-dub2016record_146-0}

From 2010 to 2016, Dublin Airport saw an increase of nearly 9.5 million passengers in its annual traffic,^[\[142\]](#cite_note-dub2016record-146)^ as the number of commercial aircraft movements has similarly followed a growth trend from 163,703 in 2013 to 191,233 in 2015.^[\[143\]](#cite_note-147)^{#cite_ref-147}

In 2019, Dublin Airport was the 12th busiest airport in Europe, with almost 33 million passengers passing through the airport.  

#### Other air transport {#Other_air_transport}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=30 "Edit section: Other air transport")\]

Dublin is also served by [Weston Airport](/wiki/Weston_Airport "Weston Airport") and other small facilities, by a range of helicopter operators, and the military and some State services use [Casement Aerodrome](/wiki/Casement_Aerodrome "Casement Aerodrome") nearby.  

Education {#Education}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=31 "Edit section: Education")\]

Dublin is the largest centre of education in Ireland, and is home to four universities and a number of other higher education institutions. It was the European Capital of Science in 2012.^[\[144\]](#cite_note-148)^^[\[145\]](#cite_note-149)^{#cite_ref-149}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Trinity_College.jpg/220px-Trinity_College.jpg)](/wiki/File:Trinity_College.jpg) [Trinity College](/wiki/Trinity_College_Dublin "Trinity College Dublin") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Long_Room_Interior%2C_Trinity_College_Dublin%2C_Ireland_-_Diliff.jpg/220px-Long_Room_Interior%2C_Trinity_College_Dublin%2C_Ireland_-_Diliff.jpg)](/wiki/File:Long_Room_Interior,_Trinity_College_Dublin,_Ireland_-_Diliff.jpg) The Old Library at [Trinity College](/wiki/Trinity_College_Dublin "Trinity College Dublin")

The [University of Dublin](/wiki/University_of_Dublin "University of Dublin") is the oldest university in Ireland, dating from the 16th century, and is located in the city centre. Its sole constituent college, [Trinity College](/wiki/Trinity_College_Dublin "Trinity College Dublin") (TCD), was established by [Royal Charter](/wiki/Royal_Charter "Royal Charter") in 1592 under [Elizabeth I](/wiki/Elizabeth_I_of_England "Elizabeth I of England"). It was closed to Roman Catholics until 1793, and the [Catholic hierarchy](/wiki/Catholic_Church_hierarchy "Catholic Church hierarchy") then banned Roman Catholics from attending until 1970.^[\[146\]](#cite_note-150)^ It is situated in the city centre, on College Green, and has over 18,000 students.^[\[147\]](#cite_note-151)^{#cite_ref-151}

The [National University of Ireland](/wiki/National_University_of_Ireland "National University of Ireland") (NUI) has its seat in Dublin, which is also the location of the associated *constituent university* of [University College Dublin](/wiki/University_College_Dublin "University College Dublin") (UCD), which has over 30,000 students. Founded in 1854, it is now the largest university in Ireland. UCD's main campus is at Belfield, about 5 km (3 mi) from the city centre, in the southeastern suburbs.

As of 2019, Dublin's principal, and Ireland's largest, institution for technological education and research, [Dublin Institute of Technology](/wiki/Dublin_Institute_of_Technology "Dublin Institute of Technology") (DIT), with origins in 1887, has merged with two major suburban third level institutions, [Institute of Technology, Tallaght](/wiki/Institute_of_Technology,_Tallaght "Institute of Technology, Tallaght") and [Institute of Technology, Blanchardstown](/wiki/Institute_of_Technology,_Blanchardstown "Institute of Technology, Blanchardstown"), to form [Technological University Dublin](/wiki/Technological_University_Dublin "Technological University Dublin"), Ireland's second largest university by student population. The new university offers a wide range of courses in areas include engineering, architecture, the sciences, health, journalism, digital media, hospitality, business, art and design, music and the humanities programmes, and has three long-term campuses, at [Grangegorman](/wiki/Grangegorman "Grangegorman"), Tallaght and Blanchardstown.

[Dublin City University](/wiki/Dublin_City_University "Dublin City University") (DCU), formerly the [National Institute for Higher Education](/wiki/National_Institute_for_Higher_Education "National Institute for Higher Education") (NIHE) Dublin, offers courses in business, engineering, science, communication courses, languages and primary education. It has around 16,000 students, and its main campus is located about 7 km (4 mi) from the city centre, in the northern suburbs. Aside from the main Glasnevin Campus, the Drumcondra campuses includes the former [St. Patrick's College of Education, Drumcondra](/wiki/St._Patrick%27s_College_of_Education,_Drumcondra "St. Patrick's College of Education, Drumcondra") now also hosting students from the nearby [Mater Dei Institute of Education](/wiki/Mater_Dei_Institute_of_Education "Mater Dei Institute of Education") and students from the [Church of Ireland College of Education](/wiki/Church_of_Ireland_College_of_Education "Church of Ireland College of Education") at the DCU Campus at [All Hallows College](/wiki/All_Hallows_College "All Hallows College").^[\[148\]](#cite_note-152)^{#cite_ref-152}

The [Royal College of Surgeons in Ireland](/wiki/Royal_College_of_Surgeons_in_Ireland "Royal College of Surgeons in Ireland") (RCSI) conducts a medical school which is both a university (since 2019) and a recognised college of the NUI, and is situated at [St. Stephen's Green](/wiki/St._Stephen%27s_Green "St. Stephen's Green") in the city centre; there are also large medical schools within UCD and Trinity College. The [National College of Art and Design](/wiki/National_College_of_Art_and_Design "National College of Art and Design") (NCAD) provides education and research in art, design and media. The [National College of Ireland](/wiki/National_College_of_Ireland "National College of Ireland") (NCI) is also based in Dublin, as well as the [Economic and Social Research Institute](/wiki/Economic_and_Social_Research_Institute "Economic and Social Research Institute"), a social science research institute, on [Sir John Rogerson's Quay](/wiki/Sir_John_Rogerson%27s_Quay "Sir John Rogerson's Quay"), and the [Dublin Institute for Advanced Studies](/wiki/Dublin_Institute_for_Advanced_Studies "Dublin Institute for Advanced Studies").

The [Institute of International and European Affairs](/wiki/Institute_of_International_and_European_Affairs "Institute of International and European Affairs") is also in Dublin. [Dublin Business School](/wiki/Dublin_Business_School "Dublin Business School") (DBS) is Ireland's largest private third level institution with over 9,000 students located on Aungier Street, and [Griffith College Dublin](/wiki/Griffith_College_Dublin "Griffith College Dublin") has its main facility in Portobello. There are also smaller specialised colleges, including [The Gaiety School of Acting](/wiki/The_Gaiety_School_of_Acting "The Gaiety School of Acting"). The Irish public administration and management training centre has its base in Dublin, the Institute of Public Administration provides a range of undergraduate and post graduate awards via the National University of Ireland and in some instances, Queen's University Belfast.

Dublin is also home to the [Royal Irish Academy](/wiki/Royal_Irish_Academy "Royal Irish Academy"), membership of which is considered Ireland's highest academic honour.^[\[149\]](#cite_note-153)^^\[*[independent source needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Independent_sources "Wikipedia:Independent sources")*\]^{#cite_ref-153}

The suburban town of Dún Laoghaire is home to the [Dún Laoghaire Institute of Art, Design and Technology](/wiki/D%C3%BAn_Laoghaire_Institute_of_Art,_Design_and_Technology "Dún Laoghaire Institute of Art, Design and Technology") (IADT), which supports training and research in art, design, business, psychology and media technology. Dublin joined the UNESCO Global Network of Learning Cities in 2019.^[\[150\]](#cite_note-154)^{#cite_ref-154}
