{#cite_ref-155}

The City of Dublin is the area administered by [Dublin City Council](/wiki/Dublin_City_Council "Dublin City Council"). The traditional [County Dublin](/wiki/County_Dublin "County Dublin") includes the city and the administrative counties of [Dún Laoghaire--Rathdown](/wiki/D%C3%BAn_Laoghaire%E2%80%93Rathdown "Dún Laoghaire–Rathdown"), [Fingal](/wiki/Fingal "Fingal") and [South Dublin](/wiki/South_Dublin "South Dublin"). The [Greater Dublin Area](/wiki/Greater_Dublin_Area "Greater Dublin Area") includes County Dublin and the adjoining counties, [County Kildare](/wiki/County_Kildare "County Kildare"), [County Meath](/wiki/County_Meath "County Meath") and [County Wicklow](/wiki/County_Wicklow "County Wicklow").

In the [2022 census](/wiki/2022_census_of_Ireland "2022 census of Ireland"), the population of the City of Dublin was 592,713,^[\[3\]](#cite_note-2022mapdcc-3)^ while the population of Dublin city and suburbs was 1,263,219.^[\[13\]](#cite_note-2022mapdcands-15)^ County Dublin had a population of 1,458,154,^[\[167\]](#cite_note-2022mapcodub-171)^ and the population of the Greater Dublin Area was 2,082,605.^[\[168\]](#cite_note-:1-172)^^[\[169\]](#cite_note-173)^{#cite_ref-173}

Of the population of Dublin city and its suburbs, 62.9% (794,925) were born in Dublin, 26.6% (336,021) were born outside of Ireland, while the remaining 10.5% (132,273) were born in a county other than Dublin.^[\[170\]](#cite_note-174)^{#cite_ref-174}

After [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), Italians were by far the largest immigrant group in both Dublin and Ireland and became synonymous with the catering and restaurant landscape.^[\[171\]](#cite_note-rteArchives1972-175)^^[\[172\]](#cite_note-176)^ Since the late 1990s, Dublin has experienced a significant level of net immigration, with the greatest numbers coming from the European Union, especially the United Kingdom, Poland and Lithuania.^[\[173\]](#cite_note-177)^ There is also immigration from outside Europe, including from Pakistan, Brazil, the Philippines, China, India and Nigeria. Dublin is home to a greater proportion of newer arrivals than any other part of the country. Sixty percent of Ireland's Asian population lives in Dublin.^[\[174\]](#cite_note-178)^{#cite_ref-178}

The capital attracts the largest proportion of non-Catholic migrants from other countries. Increased secularisation in Ireland has prompted a drop in regular Catholic church attendance in Dublin from over 90 percent in the mid-1970s down to 14 percent according to a 2011 survey and less than 2% in some areas^[\[175\]](#cite_note-179)^^[\[176\]](#cite_note-180)^ As of the [2016 census](/wiki/2016_census_of_Ireland "2016 census of Ireland"), 68.2% of Dublin's population identified as Catholic, 12.7% as other stated religions, with 19.1% having no religion or no religion stated.^[\[177\]](#cite_note-181)^{#cite_ref-181}

According to the 2022 census, the population of [County Dublin](/wiki/County_Dublin "County Dublin") self-identified as 80.4% white (68.0% white Irish, 12.0% other white and 0.4% Irish traveller), 5.8% Asian, 3.0% mixed backgrounds, 2.2% [Black](/wiki/Black_people_in_Ireland "Black people in Ireland") and 8.5% not stated.^[\[178\]](#cite_note-182)^ In the same census, the ethnic makeup of Dublin city was 76.81% white (including 64.23% white Irish and 12.19% other white people), 12.98% not stated, 5.11% Asian, 3.50% other and 1.58% [black](/wiki/Black_people_in_Ireland "Black people in Ireland").^[\[179\]](#cite_note-183)^{#cite_ref-183}

As of July 2018^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit)^, there were 1,367 families within the Dublin region living in homeless accommodation or other emergency housing.^[\[180\]](#cite_note-184)^{#cite_ref-184}  

Culture {#Culture}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=33 "Edit section: Culture")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/National_Museum_of_Ireland.jpg/220px-National_Museum_of_Ireland.jpg)](/wiki/File:National_Museum_of_Ireland.jpg) [National Museum of Ireland](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Ireland "National Museum of Ireland")  

### The arts {#The_arts}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=34 "Edit section: The arts")\]

Dublin has a significant literary history, and produced many literary figures, including [Nobel laureates](/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature "Nobel Prize in Literature") [William Butler Yeats](/wiki/William_Butler_Yeats "William Butler Yeats"), [George Bernard Shaw](/wiki/George_Bernard_Shaw "George Bernard Shaw") and [Samuel Beckett](/wiki/Samuel_Beckett "Samuel Beckett"). Other influential writers and playwrights include [Oscar Wilde](/wiki/Oscar_Wilde "Oscar Wilde"), [Jonathan Swift](/wiki/Jonathan_Swift "Jonathan Swift") and the creator of [Dracula](/wiki/Dracula "Dracula"), [Bram Stoker](/wiki/Bram_Stoker "Bram Stoker"). It is also the location of key and notable works of [James Joyce](/wiki/James_Joyce "James Joyce"), including *[Ulysses](/wiki/Ulysses_(novel) "Ulysses (novel)")* , which is set in Dublin and includes much topical detail. *[Dubliners](/wiki/Dubliners "Dubliners")* is a collection of short stories by Joyce about incidents and typical characters of the city during the early 20th century. Other renowned writers include [J. M. Synge](/wiki/J._M._Synge "J. M. Synge"), [Seán O'Casey](/wiki/Se%C3%A1n_O%27Casey "Seán O'Casey"), [Brendan Behan](/wiki/Brendan_Behan "Brendan Behan"), [Maeve Binchy](/wiki/Maeve_Binchy "Maeve Binchy"), [John Banville](/wiki/John_Banville "John Banville") and [Roddy Doyle](/wiki/Roddy_Doyle "Roddy Doyle"). Ireland's biggest libraries and literary museums are found in Dublin, including the [National Print Museum of Ireland](/wiki/National_Print_Museum_of_Ireland "National Print Museum of Ireland") and [National Library of Ireland](/wiki/National_Library_of_Ireland "National Library of Ireland"). In July 2010, Dublin was named as a UNESCO [City of Literature](/wiki/City_of_Literature "City of Literature"), joining [Edinburgh](/wiki/Edinburgh "Edinburgh"), [Melbourne](/wiki/Melbourne "Melbourne") and [Iowa City](/wiki/Iowa_City "Iowa City") with the permanent title.^[\[181\]](#cite_note-185)^{#cite_ref-185}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/KellsFol032vChristEnthroned.jpg/220px-KellsFol032vChristEnthroned.jpg)](/wiki/File:KellsFol032vChristEnthroned.jpg) [Book of Kells](/wiki/Book_of_Kells "Book of Kells")

[Handel](/wiki/Handel "Handel")'s oratorio [Messiah](/wiki/Messiah_(Handel) "Messiah (Handel)") was first performed at [Neal's Music Hall](/wiki/Neale%27s_Musick_Hall,_Dublin "Neale's Musick Hall, Dublin"), in [Fishamble Street](/wiki/Fishamble_Street "Fishamble Street"), on 13 April [1742](/wiki/1742_in_Ireland "1742 in Ireland").

There are several theatres within the city centre, and various well-known actors have emerged from the Dublin theatrical scene, including [Noel Purcell](/wiki/Noel_Purcell_(actor) "Noel Purcell (actor)"), [Michael Gambon](/wiki/Michael_Gambon "Michael Gambon"), [Brendan Gleeson](/wiki/Brendan_Gleeson "Brendan Gleeson"), [Stephen Rea](/wiki/Stephen_Rea "Stephen Rea"), [Colin Farrell](/wiki/Colin_Farrell "Colin Farrell"), [Colm Meaney](/wiki/Colm_Meaney "Colm Meaney") and [Gabriel Byrne](/wiki/Gabriel_Byrne "Gabriel Byrne"). The best known theatres include the [Gaiety](/wiki/Gaiety_Theatre,_Dublin "Gaiety Theatre, Dublin"), [Abbey](/wiki/Abbey_Theatre "Abbey Theatre"), [Olympia](/wiki/Olympia_Theatre,_Dublin "Olympia Theatre, Dublin"), [Gate](/wiki/Gate_Theatre "Gate Theatre"), and [Grand Canal](/wiki/Grand_Canal_Theatre "Grand Canal Theatre"). The Gaiety specialises in musical and operatic productions, and also opens its doors after the evening theatre production to host a variety of live music, dancing, and films. The Abbey was founded in 1904 by a group that included [Yeats](/wiki/William_Butler_Yeats "William Butler Yeats") with the aim of promoting indigenous literary talent. It went on to provide a breakthrough for some of the city's most famous writers, such as [Synge](/wiki/J._M._Synge "J. M. Synge"), Yeats himself and George Bernard Shaw. The Gate was founded in 1928 to promote European and American Avant Garde works. The Grand Canal Theatre is a newer 2,111 capacity theatre which opened in 2010 in the [Grand Canal Dock](/wiki/Grand_Canal_Dock "Grand Canal Dock") area.

Apart from being the focus of the country's literature and theatre, Dublin is also the focal point for much of [Irish art](/wiki/Irish_art "Irish art") and the Irish artistic scene. The [Book of Kells](/wiki/Book_of_Kells "Book of Kells"), a world-famous manuscript produced by Celtic monks in AD 800 and an example of [Insular art](/wiki/Insular_art "Insular art"), is on display in [Trinity College](/wiki/Trinity_College_Dublin "Trinity College Dublin"). The [Chester Beatty Library](/wiki/Chester_Beatty_Library "Chester Beatty Library") houses a collection of manuscripts, miniature paintings, prints, drawings, rare books and [decorative arts](/wiki/Decorative_art "Decorative art") assembled by American mining millionaire (and honorary Irish citizen) [Sir Alfred Chester Beatty](/wiki/Sir_Alfred_Chester_Beatty "Sir Alfred Chester Beatty") (1875--1968). The collections date from 2700 BCE onwards and are drawn from Asia, the Middle East, North Africa and Europe.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Image_Floor_Mosaic_of_City_Hall_of_Dublin.jpg/220px-Image_Floor_Mosaic_of_City_Hall_of_Dublin.jpg)](/wiki/File:Image_Floor_Mosaic_of_City_Hall_of_Dublin.jpg) Mosaic of the coat of arms of Dublin on the floor of City Hall

In addition public [art galleries](/wiki/Art_gallery "Art gallery") are found across the city and are free to visit, including the [Irish Museum of Modern Art](/wiki/Irish_Museum_of_Modern_Art "Irish Museum of Modern Art"), the [National Gallery](/wiki/National_Gallery_of_Ireland "National Gallery of Ireland"), the [Hugh Lane Municipal Gallery](/wiki/Hugh_Lane_Municipal_Gallery "Hugh Lane Municipal Gallery"), [the Douglas Hyde Gallery](/wiki/The_Douglas_Hyde_Gallery "The Douglas Hyde Gallery"), the [Project Arts Centre](/wiki/Project_Arts_Centre "Project Arts Centre") and the exhibition space of the [Royal Hibernian Academy](/wiki/Royal_Hibernian_Academy "Royal Hibernian Academy"). Private galleries in Dublin include Green on Red Gallery, [Kerlin Gallery](/wiki/Kerlin_Gallery "Kerlin Gallery"), Kevin Kavanagh Gallery and Mother's Tankstation.^[\[182\]](#cite_note-186)^{#cite_ref-186}

Three branches of the [National Museum of Ireland](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Ireland "National Museum of Ireland") are located in Dublin: [Archaeology](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Ireland_%E2%80%93_Archaeology "National Museum of Ireland – Archaeology") in [Kildare Street](/wiki/Kildare_Street "Kildare Street"), [Decorative Arts and History](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Ireland_%E2%80%93_Decorative_Arts_and_History "National Museum of Ireland – Decorative Arts and History") in [Collins Barracks](/wiki/Collins_Barracks "Collins Barracks") and [Natural History](/wiki/Natural_History_Museum_(Ireland) "Natural History Museum (Ireland)") in [Merrion Street](/wiki/Merrion_Street "Merrion Street").^[\[183\]](#cite_note-187)^ Dublin is home to the [National College of Art and Design](/wiki/National_College_of_Art_and_Design "National College of Art and Design"), which dates from 1746, and [Dublin Institute of Design](/wiki/Dublin_Institute_of_Design "Dublin Institute of Design"), founded in 1991. [Dublinia](/wiki/Dublinia "Dublinia") is a [living history](/wiki/Living_history "Living history") attraction showcasing the Viking and Medieval history of the city.{#cite_ref-187}

Dublin has long had an 'underground' arts scene, with Temple Bar hosting artists in the 1980s, and spaces such as the Project Arts Centre acting as a hub for collectives and new exhibitions. *[The Guardian](/wiki/The_Guardian "The Guardian")* noted that Dublin's independent and underground arts flourished during the economic recession of  2010.^[\[184\]](#cite_note-188)^ Dublin also has many dramatic, musical and operatic companies, including Festival Productions, Lyric Opera Productions, the Pioneers' Musical \& Dramatic Society, [Rathmines and Rathgar Musical Society](/wiki/Rathmines_and_Rathgar_Musical_Society "Rathmines and Rathgar Musical Society"), the Glasnevin Musical Society, Third Day Chorale, Second Age Theatre Company, [Irish National Opera](/wiki/Irish_National_Opera "Irish National Opera").{#cite_ref-188}

Dublin was shortlisted to be [World Design Capital](/wiki/World_Design_Capital "World Design Capital") 2014.^[\[185\]](#cite_note-189)^ [Taoiseach](/wiki/Taoiseach "Taoiseach") [Enda Kenny](/wiki/Enda_Kenny "Enda Kenny") was quoted to say that Dublin "would be an ideal candidate to host the World Design Capital in 2014".^[\[186\]](#cite_note-190)^{#cite_ref-190}

In October 2021, Dublin was shortlisted for the [European Commission](/wiki/European_Commission "European Commission")'s 2022 European Capital of Smart Tourism award along with [Bordeaux](/wiki/Bordeaux "Bordeaux"), [Copenhagen](/wiki/Copenhagen "Copenhagen"), [Florence](/wiki/Florence "Florence"), [Ljubljana](/wiki/Ljubljana "Ljubljana"), [Palma de Mallorca](/wiki/Palma_de_Mallorca "Palma de Mallorca") and [Valencia](/wiki/Valencia "Valencia").^[\[187\]](#cite_note-191)^{#cite_ref-191}  

### Entertainment {#Entertainment}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=35 "Edit section: Entertainment")\]

Dublin has a vibrant nightlife and is reputedly one of Europe's most youthful cities, with an estimate of 50% of citizens being younger than 25.^[\[188\]](#cite_note-axdqer-192)^^[\[189\]](#cite_note-193)^ There are many pubs across the city centre, with the area around [St. Stephen's Green](/wiki/St._Stephen%27s_Green "St. Stephen's Green") and [Grafton Street](/wiki/Grafton_Street "Grafton Street"), especially [Harcourt Street](/wiki/Harcourt_Street "Harcourt Street"), [Camden Street](/wiki/Camden_Street "Camden Street"), [Wexford Street](/wiki/Wexford_Street "Wexford Street") and [Leeson Street](/wiki/Leeson_Street "Leeson Street"), the location of many nightclubs and pubs.{#cite_ref-193}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Temple_Bar_Dublin_at_Night.jpg/220px-Temple_Bar_Dublin_at_Night.jpg)](/wiki/File:Temple_Bar_Dublin_at_Night.jpg) [Temple Bar](/wiki/Temple_Bar,_Dublin "Temple Bar, Dublin")

The best known area for nightlife is [Temple Bar](/wiki/Temple_Bar,_Dublin "Temple Bar, Dublin"), south of the River Liffey. The area has become popular among tourists, including [stag](/wiki/Bachelor_Party "Bachelor Party") and [hen](/wiki/Bachelorette_Party "Bachelorette Party") parties from the UK.^[\[190\]](#cite_note-194)^ It was developed as Dublin's cultural quarter and does retain this spirit as a centre for small arts productions, photographic and artists' studios, and in the form of street performers and small music venues; however, it has been criticised as overpriced, false and dirty by Lonely Planet.^[\[191\]](#cite_note-195)^ The areas around Leeson Street, Harcourt Street, South William Street and Camden/George's Street are popular nightlife spots for locals.{#cite_ref-195}  

### Music {#Music}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=36 "Edit section: Music")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Luke_Kelly_South_King_Street.jpg/170px-Luke_Kelly_South_King_Street.jpg)](/wiki/File:Luke_Kelly_South_King_Street.jpg) Statue of [Luke Kelly](/wiki/Luke_Kelly "Luke Kelly"), member of [The Dubliners](/wiki/The_Dubliners "The Dubliners"), on South King Street

Live music is played on streets and at venues throughout Dublin, and the city has produced several musicians and groups of international success, including [the Dubliners](/wiki/The_Dubliners "The Dubliners"), [Thin Lizzy](/wiki/Thin_Lizzy "Thin Lizzy"), [the Boomtown Rats](/wiki/The_Boomtown_Rats "The Boomtown Rats"), [U2](/wiki/U2 "U2"), [the Script](/wiki/The_Script "The Script"), [Sinéad O'Connor](/wiki/Sin%C3%A9ad_O%27Connor "Sinéad O'Connor"), [Boyzone](/wiki/Boyzone "Boyzone"), [Kodaline](/wiki/Kodaline "Kodaline"), [Fontaines D.C.](/wiki/Fontaines_D.C. "Fontaines D.C.") and [Westlife](/wiki/Westlife "Westlife"). Dublin has several mid-range venues that host live music throughout the week, including [Whelans](/wiki/Whelan%27s_(music_venue) "Whelan's (music venue)") and [Vicar Street](/wiki/Vicar_Street "Vicar Street").^[\[192\]](#cite_note-196)^^[\[193\]](#cite_note-197)^ The [3Arena](/wiki/3Arena "3Arena") venue in the [Dublin Docklands](/wiki/Dublin_Docklands "Dublin Docklands") plays host to visiting global performers.{#cite_ref-197}  

### Shopping {#Shopping}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=37 "Edit section: Shopping")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Moore_Street_market%2C_Dublin.jpg/220px-Moore_Street_market%2C_Dublin.jpg)](/wiki/File:Moore_Street_market,_Dublin.jpg) [Moore Street](/wiki/Moore_Street "Moore Street") Market [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Grafton_St%2C_Dublin.jpg/220px-Grafton_St%2C_Dublin.jpg)](/wiki/File:Grafton_St,_Dublin.jpg) [Grafton Street](/wiki/Grafton_Street "Grafton Street")

Dublin city centre is a popular shopping destination for both locals and tourists. The city has numerous shopping districts, particularly around [Grafton Street](/wiki/Grafton_Street_(Dublin) "Grafton Street (Dublin)") and [Henry Street](/wiki/Henry_Street_(Dublin) "Henry Street (Dublin)"). The city centre is also the location of large department stores, including [Arnotts](/wiki/Arnotts_(Ireland) "Arnotts (Ireland)"), [Brown Thomas](/wiki/Brown_Thomas "Brown Thomas") and (prior to its 2015 closure) [Clerys](/wiki/Clerys "Clerys").

While the city has seen the loss of some traditional market sites, [Moore Street](/wiki/Moore_Street "Moore Street") remains one of the city's oldest trading districts.^[\[194\]](#cite_note-198)^ There has also been some growth in local farmers' markets and other markets.^[\[195\]](#cite_note-199)^^[\[196\]](#cite_note-200)^ In 2007, [Dublin Food Co-op](/wiki/Dublin_Food_Co-op "Dublin Food Co-op") relocated to a warehouse in [The Liberties](/wiki/The_Liberties "The Liberties") area, where it is home to market and community events.^[\[197\]](#cite_note-201)^^[\[198\]](#cite_note-202)^ Suburban Dublin has several modern retail centres, including [Dundrum Town Centre](/wiki/Dundrum_Town_Centre "Dundrum Town Centre"), [Blanchardstown Centre](/wiki/Blanchardstown_Centre "Blanchardstown Centre"), [the Square](/wiki/The_Square_Shopping_Centre "The Square Shopping Centre") in Tallaght, [Liffey Valley Shopping Centre](/wiki/Liffey_Valley_Shopping_Centre "Liffey Valley Shopping Centre") in [Clondalkin](/wiki/Clondalkin "Clondalkin"), [Omni Shopping Centre](/wiki/Omni_Shopping_Centre "Omni Shopping Centre") in [Santry](/wiki/Santry "Santry"), [Nutgrove Shopping Centre](/wiki/Nutgrove_Shopping_Centre "Nutgrove Shopping Centre") in [Rathfarnham](/wiki/Rathfarnham "Rathfarnham"), [Northside Shopping Centre](/wiki/Northside_Shopping_Centre "Northside Shopping Centre") in [Coolock](/wiki/Coolock "Coolock") and [Swords Pavilions](/wiki/Swords_Pavilions "Swords Pavilions") in [Swords](/wiki/Swords,_Dublin "Swords, Dublin").{#cite_ref-202}  

### Media {#Media}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=38 "Edit section: Media")\]

Dublin is the centre of both media and communications in Ireland, with many newspapers, radio stations, television stations and telephone companies based there. [RTÉ](/wiki/RT%C3%89 "RTÉ") is Ireland's national state broadcaster, and is based in [Donnybrook](/wiki/Donnybrook,_Dublin "Donnybrook, Dublin"). [Fair City](/wiki/Fair_City "Fair City") is RTÉ's soap opera, located in the fictional Dublin suburb of *Carraigstown*.

[Virgin Media Television](/wiki/Virgin_Media_Television_(Ireland) "Virgin Media Television (Ireland)"), [eir Sport](/wiki/Eir_Sport "Eir Sport"), [MTV Ireland](/wiki/MTV_Ireland "MTV Ireland") and [Sky News](/wiki/Sky_News "Sky News") are also based in the city. The headquarters of [An Post](/wiki/An_Post "An Post") and telecommunications companies such as [Eir](/wiki/Eir_(telecommunications) "Eir (telecommunications)"), as well as mobile operators [Vodafone](/wiki/Vodafone_Ireland "Vodafone Ireland") and [3](/wiki/Three_Ireland "Three Ireland") are all located there. Dublin is also the headquarters of national newspapers such as *[The Irish Times](/wiki/The_Irish_Times "The Irish Times")* and *[Irish Independent](/wiki/Irish_Independent "Irish Independent")* , as well as local newspapers such as *[The Evening Herald](/wiki/Evening_Herald "Evening Herald")*.

As well as being home to [RTÉ Radio](/wiki/RT%C3%89_Radio "RTÉ Radio"), Dublin also hosts the national radio networks [Today FM](/wiki/Today_FM "Today FM") and [Newstalk](/wiki/Newstalk "Newstalk"), and local stations. Commercial radio stations based in the city include [4fm](/wiki/Classic_Hits_4FM "Classic Hits 4FM") (94.9 [MHz](/wiki/Hertz "Hertz")), [Dublin's 98FM](/wiki/Dublin%27s_98FM "Dublin's 98FM") (98.1 MHz), [Radio Nova 100FM](/wiki/Radio_Nova_100FM_(Ireland) "Radio Nova 100FM (Ireland)") (100.3 MHz), [Q102](/wiki/Dublin%27s_Q102 "Dublin's Q102") (102.2 MHz), [SPIN 1038](/wiki/SPIN_1038 "SPIN 1038") (103.8 MHz), [FM104](/wiki/FM104 "FM104") (104.4 MHz), [Sunshine 106.8](/wiki/Sunshine_106.8 "Sunshine 106.8") (106.8 MHz). There are also numerous community and special interest stations, including [Dublin City FM](/wiki/Dublin_City_FM "Dublin City FM") (103.2 MHz), [Dublin South FM](/wiki/Dublin_South_FM "Dublin South FM") (93.9 MHz), [Liffey Sound FM](/wiki/Liffey_Sound_FM "Liffey Sound FM") (96.4 MHz), [Near FM](/wiki/Near_fm_90.3 "Near fm 90.3") (90.3 MHz), and [Raidió Na Life](/wiki/Raidi%C3%B3_Na_Life "Raidió Na Life") (106.4 MHz).  

### Sport {#Sport}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=39 "Edit section: Sport")\]  

#### GAA {#GAA}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=40 "Edit section: GAA")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Croke_Park_from_the_Hill_-_2004_All-Ireland_Football_Championship_Final.jpg/220px-Croke_Park_from_the_Hill_-_2004_All-Ireland_Football_Championship_Final.jpg)](/wiki/File:Croke_Park_from_the_Hill_-_2004_All-Ireland_Football_Championship_Final.jpg) [Croke Park](/wiki/Croke_Park "Croke Park")

[Croke Park](/wiki/Croke_Park "Croke Park") is the largest sport stadium in Ireland. The headquarters of the [Gaelic Athletic Association](/wiki/Gaelic_Athletic_Association "Gaelic Athletic Association"), it has a capacity of 82,300. It is the third-largest stadium in Europe after [Nou Camp](/wiki/Nou_Camp "Nou Camp") in Barcelona and [Wembley Stadium](/wiki/Wembley_Stadium "Wembley Stadium") in London.^[\[199\]](#cite_note-203)^ It hosts the premier [Gaelic football](/wiki/Gaelic_football "Gaelic football") and [hurling](/wiki/Hurling "Hurling") games, [international rules football](/wiki/International_rules_football "International rules football") and irregularly other sporting and non-sporting events including concerts. Muhammad Ali fought there in 1972 and it played host to the opening and closing ceremonies of the 2003 [Special Olympics](/wiki/Special_Olympics "Special Olympics"). It also has conference and banqueting facilities. There is a GAA Museum there and tours of the stadium are offered, including a rooftop walk of the stadium. During the redevelopment of [Lansdowne Road](/wiki/Lansdowne_Road "Lansdowne Road"), Croke Park played host to the [Irish Rugby Union Team](/wiki/Ireland_national_rugby_union_team "Ireland national rugby union team") and [Republic of Ireland national football team](/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland_national_football_team "Republic of Ireland national football team") as well as hosting the [Heineken Cup](/wiki/Heineken_Cup "Heineken Cup") rugby [2008--09 semi-final](/wiki/2008%E2%80%9309_Heineken_Cup#Semi-finals "2008–09 Heineken Cup") between Munster and Leinster, which set a world record attendance for a club rugby match.^[\[200\]](#cite_note-204)^ The [Dublin GAA](/wiki/Dublin_GAA "Dublin GAA") team plays most of their home league hurling games at [Parnell Park](/wiki/Parnell_Park "Parnell Park").{#cite_ref-204}  

#### Rugby Union {#Rugby_Union}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=41 "Edit section: Rugby Union")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Dublin_aviva_stadium.jpg/220px-Dublin_aviva_stadium.jpg)](/wiki/File:Dublin_aviva_stadium.jpg) [Aviva Stadium](/wiki/Aviva_Stadium "Aviva Stadium")

[IRFU Stadium Lansdowne Road](/wiki/Lansdowne_Road "Lansdowne Road") was laid out in 1874. This was the venue for home games of both the Irish Rugby Union Team and the Republic of Ireland national football team. A joint venture between the [Irish Rugby Football Union](/wiki/Irish_Rugby_Football_Union "Irish Rugby Football Union"), the [FAI](/wiki/Football_Association_of_Ireland "Football Association of Ireland") and the Government, saw it redeveloped into a new state-of-the-art 50,000 seat [Aviva Stadium](/wiki/Aviva_Stadium "Aviva Stadium"), which opened in May 2010.^[\[201\]](#cite_note-205)^ Lansdowne Road/Aviva Stadium hosted the [Heineken Cup final](/wiki/European_Rugby_Champions_Cup "European Rugby Champions Cup") in 1999, 2003, 2013, and 2023. [Rugby union](/wiki/Rugby_union "Rugby union") team [Leinster Rugby](/wiki/Leinster_Rugby "Leinster Rugby") play their competitive home games in the [RDS Arena](/wiki/RDS_Arena "RDS Arena") and the [Aviva Stadium](/wiki/Aviva_Stadium "Aviva Stadium"), while [Donnybrook Stadium](/wiki/Donnybrook_Stadium "Donnybrook Stadium") hosts their friendlies and A games, Ireland A and Women, Leinster Schools and Youths and the home club games of [All Ireland League](/wiki/AIB_League "AIB League") clubs [Old Wesley](/wiki/Old_Wesley "Old Wesley") and [Bective Rangers](/wiki/Bective_Rangers "Bective Rangers"). [County Dublin](/wiki/County_Dublin "County Dublin") is home for 13 of the senior rugby union clubs in Ireland including 5 of the 10 sides in the top division 1A.^[\[202\]](#cite_note-206)^{#cite_ref-206}  

#### Association football {#Association_football}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=42 "Edit section: Association football")\]

Dublin is home to five [League of Ireland](/wiki/League_of_Ireland "League of Ireland") association football clubs: [Bohemian](/wiki/Bohemian_F.C. "Bohemian F.C."), [Shamrock Rovers](/wiki/Shamrock_Rovers_F.C. "Shamrock Rovers F.C."), [Shelbourne](/wiki/Shelbourne_F.C. "Shelbourne F.C."), [St Patrick's Athletic](/wiki/St_Patrick%27s_Athletic_F.C. "St Patrick's Athletic F.C.") and [University College Dublin](/wiki/University_College_Dublin_A.F.C. "University College Dublin A.F.C."). The first Irish side to reach the group stages of a European competition ([2011--12 UEFA Europa League group stage](/wiki/2011%E2%80%9312_UEFA_Europa_League_group_stage "2011–12 UEFA Europa League group stage")) are [Shamrock Rovers](/wiki/Shamrock_Rovers_F.C. "Shamrock Rovers F.C."), who play at [Tallaght Stadium](/wiki/Tallaght_Stadium "Tallaght Stadium") in [South Dublin](/wiki/South_Dublin "South Dublin"). [Bohemian F.C](/wiki/Bohemian_F.C. "Bohemian F.C.") play at [Dalymount Park](/wiki/Dalymount_Park "Dalymount Park"), the oldest football stadium in the country, and home ground for the [Ireland football team](/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland_national_football_team "Republic of Ireland national football team") from 1904 to the 1970s. [St Patrick's Athletic](/wiki/St_Patrick%27s_Athletic_F.C. "St Patrick's Athletic F.C.") play at [Richmond Park](/wiki/Richmond_Park_(football_ground) "Richmond Park (football ground)"); [University College Dublin](/wiki/University_College_Dublin_A.F.C. "University College Dublin A.F.C.") at the [UCD Bowl](/wiki/UCD_Bowl "UCD Bowl") in [Dún Laoghaire--Rathdown](/wiki/D%C3%BAn_Laoghaire%E2%80%93Rathdown "Dún Laoghaire–Rathdown"); and [Shelbourne](/wiki/Shelbourne_F.C. "Shelbourne F.C.") at [Tolka Park](/wiki/Tolka_Park "Tolka Park"). Tolka Park, Dalymount Park, UCD Bowl and Tallaght Stadium, along with the [Carlisle Grounds](/wiki/Carlisle_Grounds "Carlisle Grounds") in [Bray](/wiki/Bray,_County_Wicklow "Bray, County Wicklow"), hosted all Group 3 games in the intermediary round of the [2011 UEFA Regions' Cup](/wiki/2011_UEFA_Regions%27_Cup "2011 UEFA Regions' Cup"). The [Aviva Stadium](/wiki/Aviva_Stadium "Aviva Stadium") hosted the [2011 UEFA Europa League final](/wiki/2011_UEFA_Europa_League_final "2011 UEFA Europa League final") and the [2024 UEFA Europa League final](/wiki/2024_UEFA_Europa_League_final "2024 UEFA Europa League final").^[\[203\]](#cite_note-207)^{#cite_ref-207}  

#### Cricket {#Cricket}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=43 "Edit section: Cricket")\]

Dublin has two [ODI cricket grounds](/wiki/List_of_One_Day_International_cricket_grounds "List of One Day International cricket grounds") in [Castle Avenue](/wiki/Castle_Avenue,_Dublin "Castle Avenue, Dublin") (Clontarf Cricket Club) and [Malahide Cricket Club Ground](/wiki/Malahide_Cricket_Club_Ground "Malahide Cricket Club Ground"). [College Park](/wiki/College_Park,_Dublin "College Park, Dublin") has Test status and played host to Ireland's first Test cricket match, a women's match against Pakistan in 2000.^[\[204\]](#cite_note-208)^ The men's Irish cricket team also played their first [Test match](/wiki/Test_cricket "Test cricket") against [Pakistan](/wiki/Pakistan_national_cricket_team "Pakistan national cricket team") at Malahide Cricket Club Ground during 2018.^[\[205\]](#cite_note-209)^ [Leinster Lightning](/wiki/Leinster_Lightning "Leinster Lightning") play their home [inter-provincial](/wiki/Cricket_in_Ireland#Inter-Provincial_Series "Cricket in Ireland") matches in Dublin at College Park.^[\[206\]](#cite_note-210)^{#cite_ref-210}  

#### Other {#Other}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=44 "Edit section: Other")\]

The [Dublin Marathon](/wiki/Dublin_Marathon "Dublin Marathon") has been run since 1980 at the end of October. The [Women's Mini Marathon](/wiki/Dublin_Women%27s_Mini_Marathon "Dublin Women's Mini Marathon") has been run since 1983 on the first Monday in June, which is also a bank holiday in Ireland. It is said to be the largest all female event of its kind in the world.^[\[207\]](#cite_note-211)^ The [Great Ireland Run](/wiki/Great_Ireland_Run "Great Ireland Run") takes place in Dublin's Phoenix Park in mid-April.^[\[208\]](#cite_note-212)^{#cite_ref-212}

Two Dublin baseball clubs compete in the [Irish Baseball League](/wiki/Irish_Baseball_League "Irish Baseball League").^[\[209\]](#cite_note-213)^ The Dublin Spartans and the Dublin Bay Hurricanes are both based at The O'Malley Fields at [Corkagh Park](/wiki/Corkagh_Park "Corkagh Park"). The Portmarnock Red Rox, from outside the city, competes in the Baseball Ireland B League.^[\[210\]](#cite_note-214)^{#cite_ref-214}

The Dublin area hosts [greyhound racing](/wiki/Greyhound_racing "Greyhound racing") at [Shelbourne Park](/wiki/Shelbourne_Park "Shelbourne Park") and [horse racing](/wiki/Horse_racing "Horse racing") at [Leopardstown](/wiki/Leopardstown_Racecourse "Leopardstown Racecourse"). The Dublin Horse Show takes place at the [RDS](/wiki/Royal_Dublin_Society "Royal Dublin Society"), which hosted the [Show Jumping World Championships](/wiki/Show_Jumping_World_Championships "Show Jumping World Championships") in 1982. The national boxing arena is located in [The National Stadium](/wiki/National_Stadium_(Ireland) "National Stadium (Ireland)") on the [South Circular Road](/wiki/South_Circular_Road_(Dublin) "South Circular Road (Dublin)"). The [National Basketball Arena](/wiki/National_Basketball_Arena "National Basketball Arena") is located in Tallaght, is the home of the [Irish basketball team](/wiki/Ireland_national_basketball_team "Ireland national basketball team"), the venue for the basketball league finals, and has also hosted boxing and wrestling events. [The National Aquatic Centre](/wiki/The_National_Aquatic_Centre "The National Aquatic Centre") in [Blanchardstown](/wiki/Blanchardstown "Blanchardstown") is Ireland's largest indoor water leisure facility. There are also [Gaelic Handball](/wiki/Gaelic_Handball "Gaelic Handball"), hockey and athletics stadia, most notably Morton Stadium in [Santry](/wiki/Santry "Santry"), which held the athletics events of the [2003 Special Olympics](/wiki/2003_Special_Olympics_World_Summer_Games "2003 Special Olympics World Summer Games").  

### Cuisine {#Cuisine}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=45 "Edit section: Cuisine")\]

As of the 2024 [Michelin Guide](/wiki/Michelin_Guide "Michelin Guide"), seven Dublin restaurants shared ten [Michelin stars](/wiki/Michelin_star "Michelin star") -- including [Restaurant Patrick Guilbaud](/wiki/Restaurant_Patrick_Guilbaud "Restaurant Patrick Guilbaud"), [Liath](/wiki/Liath_(restaurant) "Liath (restaurant)") and [Chapter One](/wiki/Chapter_One_(restaurant) "Chapter One (restaurant)") with two.^[\[211\]](#cite_note-215)^ Irish-born [Kevin Thornton](/wiki/Kevin_Thornton_(chef) "Kevin Thornton (chef)") was awarded two Michelin stars in 2001 -- though his restaurant, [Thornton's](/wiki/Thornton%27s_Restaurant "Thornton's Restaurant"), closed in 2016.^[\[212\]](#cite_note-216)^ The [Dublin Institute of Technology](/wiki/Dublin_Institute_of_Technology "Dublin Institute of Technology") commenced a bachelor's degree in culinary skills in 1999.^[\[213\]](#cite_note-217)^{#cite_ref-217}

Historically, Irish coffee houses and cafes were associated with those working in media.^[\[214\]](#cite_note-MacConIomaire-218)^ Since the beginning of the 21st century, with the growth of apartment living in the city, Dublin's cafés attracted younger patrons looking for an informal gathering place and an ad hoc office.^[\[214\]](#cite_note-MacConIomaire-218)^ Cafés became more popular in the city, and Irish-owned coffee chains like Java Republic, Insomnia, and O'Brien's Sandwich Bars now compete internationally. In 2008, Irish barista Stephen Morrissey won the title of World Barista Champion.^[\[215\]](#cite_note-219)^{#cite_ref-219}

Immigrant groups, such as [Chinese](/wiki/Overseas_Chinese "Overseas Chinese"), [Japanese](/wiki/Japanese_diaspora "Japanese diaspora") and [Italian](/wiki/Italian_diaspora "Italian diaspora") émigrés, have also opened restaurants around Dublin.^[\[171\]](#cite_note-rteArchives1972-175)^^[\[216\]](#cite_note-220)^ A number of South-East Asians immigrated from places such as [Hong Kong](/wiki/Hong_Kong "Hong Kong"), [Malaysia](/wiki/Malaysia "Malaysia") and [Mainland China](/wiki/Mainland_China "Mainland China") to Dublin during the 1960s and opened restaurants featuring their cuisines.^[\[217\]](#cite_note-221)^ Modern Irish adaptions of Chinese cuisine include the [Spice bag](/wiki/Spice_bag "Spice bag"), a [takeaway](/wiki/Takeaway_food "Takeaway food") dish consisting of mainly chicken, chips and vegetables.^[\[218\]](#cite_note-222)^^[\[219\]](#cite_note-223)^ In 2020, it was voted 'Ireland's Favourite Takeaway Dish' in the [Just Eat](/wiki/Just_Eat "Just Eat") National Takeaway Awards.^[\[220\]](#cite_note-224)^{#cite_ref-224}  

English and Irish languages {#English_and_Irish_languages}
----------------------------------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=46 "Edit section: English and Irish languages")\]

Dublin was traditionally a city of two languages, English and [Irish](/wiki/Irish_language "Irish language"), a situation found also in the area around it, [the Pale](/wiki/The_Pale "The Pale"). The Irish of County Dublin represented the easternmost extension of a broad central dialect area which stretched between Leinster and [Connacht](/wiki/Connacht "Connacht"), but had its own local characteristics. It may also have been influenced by the east [Ulster](/wiki/Ulster "Ulster") dialect of [County Meath](/wiki/County_Meath "County Meath") and [County Louth](/wiki/County_Louth "County Louth") to the north.^[\[221\]](#cite_note-225)^{#cite_ref-225}

In the words of a 16th-century English administrator, [William Gerard](/wiki/William_Gerard "William Gerard") (1518--1581): "All Englishe, and the most part with delight, even in Dublin, speak Irishe".^[\[222\]](#cite_note-226)^ The [Old English](/wiki/Normans_in_Ireland "Normans in Ireland") historian [Richard Stanihurst](/wiki/Richard_Stanihurst "Richard Stanihurst") (1547--1618) wrote as follows: "When their posteritie became not altogither so warie in keeping, as their ancestors were valiant in conquering, the Irish language was free dennized in the English Pale: this canker tooke such deep root, as the bodie that before was whole and sound, was by little and little festered, and in manner wholly putrified".^[\[223\]](#cite_note-227)^{#cite_ref-227}

English authorities of the Cromwellian period accepted the fact that Irish was widely spoken in the city and its surrounds. In 1655 several local dignitaries were ordered to oversee a lecture in Irish to be given in Dublin. In March 1656 a converted Catholic priest, Séamas Corcy, was appointed to preach in Irish at Bride's parish every Sunday, and was also ordered to preach at [Drogheda](/wiki/Drogheda "Drogheda") and [Athy](/wiki/Athy "Athy").^[\[224\]](#cite_note-228)^ In 1657 the English colonists in Dublin presented a petition to the Municipal Council complaining that in Dublin itself "there is Irish commonly and usually spoken".^[\[225\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBerresford_Ellis1975193-229)^{#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBerresford_Ellis1975193_229-0}

In early 18th century Dublin, Irish was the language of a group of poets and scribes led by Seán and Tadhg Ó Neachtain.^[\[226\]](#cite_note-230)^ Scribal activity in Irish persisted in Dublin right through the 18th century.^[\[227\]](#cite_note-231)^ There were still native Irish speakers in County Dublin at the time of the 1851 census.^[\[228\]](#cite_note-232)^{#cite_ref-232}

Though the number of Irish speakers declined throughout Ireland in the 19th century, the end of the century saw a [Gaelic revival](/wiki/Gaelic_revival "Gaelic revival"), centred in Dublin and accompanied by renewed literary activity.^[\[229\]](#cite_note-233)^ This was the harbinger of a steady renewal of urban Irish, though with new characteristics of its own.^[\[230\]](#cite_note-schism-234)^^[\[231\]](#cite_note-235)^{#cite_ref-235}  

### Current era {#Current_era}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=47 "Edit section: Current era")\]

The native language of most Dubliners today is English, and several local dialects are subsumed under the label [Dublin English](/wiki/Dublin_English "Dublin English"). Dublin also has many thousands of habitual Irish speakers, with the [2016 census](/wiki/2016_census_of_Ireland "2016 census of Ireland") showing that daily speakers (outside the education system) numbered 14,903. They form part of an urban Irish-speaking cohort which is generally better-educated than monoglot English speakers.^[\[232\]](#cite_note-236)^{#cite_ref-236}

The Dublin Irish-speaking cohort is supported by a number of Irish-medium schools. There are 12,950 students in the Dublin region attending 34 [gaelscoileanna](/wiki/Gaelscoil "Gaelscoil") (Irish-language primary schools) and 10 [gaelcholáistí](/wiki/Gaelchol%C3%A1iste "Gaelcholáiste") (Irish-language secondary schools).^[\[233\]](#cite_note-237)^{#cite_ref-237}

Two Irish language radio stations, [Raidió Na Life](/wiki/Raidi%C3%B3_Na_Life "Raidió Na Life") and [RTÉ Raidió na Gaeltachta](/wiki/RT%C3%89_Raidi%C3%B3_na_Gaeltachta "RTÉ Raidió na Gaeltachta"), have studios in the city, and the online station [Raidió Rí-Rá](/wiki/Raidi%C3%B3_R%C3%AD-R%C3%A1 "Raidió Rí-Rá") broadcasts from studios in the city. A number of Irish language agencies are also located in the capital. *[Conradh na Gaeilge](/wiki/Conradh_na_Gaeilge "Conradh na Gaeilge")* offers language classes and is used as a meeting place for different groups.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ The closest Gaeltacht to Dublin is the [County Meath](/wiki/County_Meath "County Meath") [Gaeltacht](/wiki/Gaeltacht "Gaeltacht") of [Ráth Cairn](/wiki/R%C3%A1th_Cairn "Ráth Cairn") and [Baile Ghib](/wiki/Baile_Ghib "Baile Ghib") which is 55 km (34 mi) away.  

International relations {#International_relations}
--------------------------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=48 "Edit section: International relations")\]

Dublin city council has an International Relations Unit, established in 2007. It works on hosting of international delegations, staff exchanges, international promotion of the city, twinning and partnerships, work with multi-city organisations such as [Eurocities](/wiki/Eurocities "Eurocities"), economic partnerships and advice to other Council units.^[\[234\]](#cite_note-DCC_IntlRels-238)^{#cite_ref-DCC_IntlRels_238-0}  

### Twin and partner cities {#Twin_and_partner_cities}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dublin&action=edit&section=49 "Edit section: Twin and partner cities")\]  
See also: [List of twin towns and sister cities in the Republic of Ireland](/wiki/List_of_twin_towns_and_sister_cities_in_the_Republic_of_Ireland "List of twin towns and sister cities in the Republic of Ireland")

Dublin is [twinned](/wiki/Twin_towns_and_sister_cities "Twin towns and sister cities") with five places:^[\[64\]](#cite_note-Facts_about_Dublin-66)^^[\[235\]](#cite_note-Dublin_Info-239)^^[\[236\]](#cite_note-240)^{#cite_ref-240}
{#cite_ref-241}{#cite_ref-liverpool1_242-0}{#cite_ref-Barcelona_244-0}{#cite_ref-246}{#cite_ref-247}

|                               City                                |                                Nation                                 | Since |
|-------------------------------------------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------|-------|
| **[San Jose](/wiki/San_Jose,_California "San Jose, California")** | United States^[\[237\]](#cite_note-241)^                              | 1986  |
| **[Liverpool](/wiki/Liverpool "Liverpool")**                      | United Kingdom^[\[238\]](#cite_note-liverpool1-242)^                  | 1997  |
| **[Barcelona](/wiki/Barcelona "Barcelona")**                      | Spain^[\[239\]](#cite_note-243)^^[\[240\]](#cite_note-Barcelona-244)^ | 1998  |
| **[Beijing](/wiki/Beijing "Beijing")**                            | China^[\[241\]](#cite_note-245)^^[\[242\]](#cite_note-246)^           | 2011  |
| **[Ramallah](/wiki/Ramallah "Ramallah")**                         | Palestine^[\[243\]](#cite_note-247)^                                  | 2023  |

The city also has "friendship" or "co-operation agreements" with a number of other cities: [Moscow](/wiki/Moscow "Moscow") (since 2009) and [St Petersburg](/wiki/St_Petersburg "St Petersburg") (since 2010) in Russia and [Guadalajara](/wiki/Guadalajara "Guadalajara") in Mexico (since 2013),^[\[244\]](#cite_note-IntRels_linked-248)^^[\[235\]](#cite_note-Dublin_Info-239)^ and has previously proposed an agreement with [Rio de Janeiro](/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro "Rio de Janeiro") also.^[\[245\]](#cite_note-249)^^[\[246\]](#cite_note-250)^ Previous agreements have included those with [Mexico City](/wiki/Mexico_City "Mexico City") (2014−2018), [Tbilisi](/wiki/Tbilisi "Tbilisi") in Georgia (2014−2017) and [Wuhan](/wiki/Wuhan "Wuhan") in China (2016−2019).{#cite_ref-250}
